properties.name: Achziv Phoenician Cemetery
properties.description:
Just on the side of the road along the shore, south of the tell of Achziv, Dr. Prauznitz excavated a Phoenician cemetary from the 10th-6th centuries. Only recently the excavations were finally published, and at the site most of the tombs are covered bt debris, industrial waste, and weeds.Still, this is about the only site in Israel where one can see clear evidence of the Phoenicians, the merchants of Lebanon who aided Solomon in building the Temple in Jerusalem.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kabul / Cabul
properties.description:
An Arab villagein the western Galille, which is probably preserving in its name a Biblical site by the same name, cf. I kings 9:13.
No excavations done at the site ever, to my knowledge.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Rosh Zayit
properties.description:
A site on a hill in the western Galille where excavations revealed a Phoenician shrine from the 5th-3ed century BCE.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Elkosh - Nahum's hometown
properties.description:
The modern moshav is supposdly at the Biblical site of Elkosh, Nahum's home town (Nahum 1:1).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Nebi Sablan
properties.description:
Holy site for the Druze people, who believe Nebi Sablan ("prophet Zevulun") is buried at the site. The shrine is just left of the placemark. You can also clearly see the big parking lot, for the annual Druze Festival which takes place on September 10.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Qedesh
properties.description:
Greko-Roman site, famous for remains of a Roman period temple, as well as Sarcophagues attributed to Deborah and Barak.
Recent excavation by Herbert and Berlin revealed a hoard of Hellenistic Bullae.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tel-kedesh

properties.name: Kh. Meroth / Meroth Synagogue
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Hazor
properties.description:
Major Canaanite and Israelite city, excvated in the 1950's by Y. Yadin, and since the 1990's by A. Ben-Tor.
Most of the excavations consentrated on the acropolis, where shrines, palaces, gates, a water reservoir, and a fort were found.
The placemark is in the center of the city, and so it enables you to see clearly the size of the city. The acropolis is in the southern part of the site.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tel-hazor

properties.name: Kh. Omrit - Herod's temple?
properties.description:
A site SW of Caesarea Philippi where an expedition from Macalster college is excavating a Roman period shrine, which they believe was built by king Herod.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Dan
properties.description:
Biblical Site. Named "Laish" (Heb. "Lion" in Canaanite times, the site was taken by the Peaple of Dan, who also changed its name. Excavations at the site yielded many finds, among them a complete Canaanite gate made of bricks, a Canaanite tomb rich in lavish finds, a large size gate complex from the Israelite period, and well as a Israelite Altar.
Yet the most important find from the site is part of an inscription where the "house of David" is mentioned, the first non-Biblical document to mention David and his dynasty.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tel-dan

properties.name: Paneon / Caesarea Philippi / Banias
properties.description:
Greco-Roman site, apparently founded in the Hellenistic period as worship center for Pan. In the first century King Herod built a temple at the site, and his grandson built a palace. The site continued to flourish in the late Roman period, mostly as a cultic site.
Many Christians are familiar with the site, because it is here that Jesus said to Peter, "You are Peter (=rock), and on this rock I shall build my church" (Mat. 16:13-20).The site has being partially excavated, and it offers a beautiful mix of archaeology, history, and nature.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/caesarea-philippi-banias

properties.name: Tomb of El-Khader
properties.description:
Holy site for the Druze, who believe El-Khader ("The Green"; Biblical Elijah) is buried at this place.A Druze pilgrimage festival is contucted every year at the site on December 25.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/caesarea-philippi-banias

properties.name: Kalaat Namrud / Nimrod Castle
properties.description:
Well preserved medieval fortress above Banyas/Caesarea Philippi. Although the style of the fortification looks like work of the Crusaders, foundation inscriptions as well as historical sources attest that the site was built by the Muslims after the expulsion of the Crusaders from the Holy Land.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Har Habtarim / Transfiguration Site?
properties.description:
Top of a mountain near the Hermon identified as the place where the Lord made a promise to Abraham (Genesis 15). According to certain Christian traditions, this is also the site of the transfiguration of Jesus (Mat. 17).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Nebi Ya'afuri
properties.description:
Holy site for the Druze, who believe Nebi Ya'afuri ("The prophet Ya'afuri) is buried at the site.An Annual Druze Pilgrimage festival is conducted at the site on September 20th.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Nain
properties.description:
Teh redroofed structure below the placemark is the church which commomates the miracle preformed at the site by Jesus, of resurrecting a son of a widow (Luke 7:11-17). The name of the village, Nain, is preserving name of the village since the Roman period.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Mt. Tabor
properties.description:
Beautifuly round shaped mountain in the Galilee identified by Christian tradition as the site of the transfiguration of Jesus (Mat. 17). A Franciscian and a Greek-Orthodox church adorn the site.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/mount-tabor

properties.name: Nazareth-Church of Mary's fear
properties.description:
A chapel on a hill near "Mount of the precipice" where according to a late Christian tradition Mary stood and saw the people on Nazareth trying to throw Jesus to his death. The chapel is also known by the name "Our Lday of the fright". It was built in 1882 over remains from the Crusaders period.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/nazareth

properties.name: Nazareth-Mount of the Precipice
properties.description:
Holy Christian site near Nazareht identified as the site where the people of Nazareth attempted to throw Jeses to his death, after he claimed at the synagogue of the village the messianic prophecies of Isaiah are about to be fulfilled in him (Luke 4).

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/nazareth

properties.name: Nazareth-St. Gabriels' church
properties.description:
The church over local spring marks the site where according to Eastern Christian tradition Gabriel the angel appeared to Mary and annunced to her of her pregnancy.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/saint-gabriel-church-in-nazareth

properties.name: "Nazareth Village"
properties.description:
A "tourist trap" - but a good one!. A site exhibiting life in Nazareth 2000 years ago. Includes actors dressed in traditional cloths, reconstructed agricultural installation and a synagogue, and aguide.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/nazareth-village

properties.name: Sepphoris - the Acropolis
properties.description:
"Sepphoris" comes from Hebrew ZIPPOR, and indeed the view from Sepphoris is like of a bird, as the tilted placemark demonstrates!.
The site was a major city in Roman times, and a big Jewish center.
Although not mentioned in the New Testament, many scholars believe Jesus visited the city often, when he joined his father to sell wooden products. Indeed at the horizon the hills of Nazareth can be seen.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/sepphoris

properties.name: Sepphoris - The Ancient Synagogue
properties.description:
The Synagogue of Sepphoris was found by accident by my colleague, O. Gutfeld, who was really looking for a spot to install the toilets for the excavators..
Althougth it is not oriented towards Jerusalem (it is the grey structure right next to the placemark!), the mosaics revealed attest to the nature of the ancient building.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/sepphoris

properties.name: Sepphoris
properties.description:
Located in the center of the Galilee, Sepphoris was a major city in Roman and Byzantine period. Large scale excavations at the site revealed a theatre, a set of insulae and streets, and the largest collection of mosaics ever found in Israel.Recently the water system of the city has being exposed and is now open to the public.
The placemark is on the Cardo of the city, perhaps were it intersected with the decumanos.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/sepphoris

properties.name: Sepphoris - The Water Reservoir
properties.description:
Water was brought to Sepphoris from a spring east of the city. They were stored in a narrow yet long water reservoir which was recently excavated by (T. Tsuk) and opened to the public.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/sepphoris

properties.name: Tel Yodfat
properties.description:
Tel Yodfat
Anceint Jewish site, famed for the battle of its inhabitents against the Romans in 67 CE. At the end of the battle one of the commanders, Yoseph Ben-Matittyahu turned himslef over to the Romans. Later, in Rome, he wrote important books about the Histrory of the Jews in the Persian, Hellenistic, and Roman period.
Excavations at the site revealed, among others, a cave full of bodeis, perheps Jewish rebels buried in haste at the end of the battle.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. Cana / Cana?
properties.description:
A tel site in western Galillee where some argue the miracle of Jesus turning water into wine (John 3) took place.
Most identify the NT Cana at Caphar Cana, an Arab village 6 km north of Nazareth.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Mashad / Gath Hefer
properties.description:
Mashad is identified with Biblical Gath Hefer, hometown of the prophet Jonah / Yona (II Kings 14:25).
His tomb is traditionally located in a cave under the mosque of the village, and revered by Jews and Moslems alike.
The Arabic name of th village, "Mashad", means "witness", a common term for places who "witnennesed" holy figures.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Cana / Kana
properties.description:
Modern Arab village Caphar Cana in the Galilee is identified by Christian tradition as the site where Jesus performed his first miracle of turning water into wine during a wedding (John 3).
To the right of the placemark you can see the white dome of the Francisciaqn church, which is actually built on top of a synagogue from the Byzantine period.
To the left of the placemark you can see the red/brown dome of the Greek-Orthodox church.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/cana

properties.name: Kh. Amudim / Umm el Umdan
properties.description:
A site in Galillee named after the pillars that have been always visible.
Excavations at the site by I. Levine revealed a Byzantine Period Synagogue. Among the finds was an inscription in Greek reading: "Yoezer the canter and Simon his brother have made this gate (=building) of the Lord of Heaven".

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Nebi Shuheib
properties.description:
Holy site for the Druze, who believe NEbi Shuheib ("Prophet Yitro" i.e. Biblical Jethro, father in law of Moses) is buried at the site.
The big parking lot in front of the site is for the Druze annual pilgrimage festival, which takes place on April 25.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/nebi-shuayb

properties.name: Horns of Hattin
properties.description:
Geologically an unactive volcano top, but historically a very hot spot. On July 4 1187 CE the Muslim soldiers of Salah es-din defeted here the Crusaders knights, and even took over the "the Holy Cross" relic.
In the middle ages some pilgrims suggested this is the site of the miraculous multiplication of the fish and bread (mat. 14:13-18). Others believed this is the "Mount of the Beatitudeus" (Mat. 5).
In 1962 the "Church of the Vision of the Lord" identified the site as the place where Jesus chose his 12 deciples (Mark 5:13-15), and as the place where the Bible was written (Deut. 27:2-3).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Belvoir
properties.description:
Well preserved Crusader fortress which monitored the road in the JOrdan Valley.The sattelite image shows clearly the layout of the site!.
South of the site is an outdoor display of Israeli contemporary art.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/belvoir

properties.name: Ubeidiya - Biblical "Garden of Eden"?
properties.description:
One of the most important prehistorical sites in the Holy Land. Located close to the sea of Galilee, excavations at the site yielded abundnace of bones of mammals, reptiles, fish and birds. Flints attest that humans dwelt in comfort for a long time at the site, and perhaps the fame of the site sourced the Biblical concept of "Garden of Eden".

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Hamath Gader
properties.description:
Complex of an ancient spa which is active to this day. The ancient spa complex was excavated by Y. Hirschfeld and G. Soler in the 1980's, while Sukenik in the 1930's found an ancient synagogue at the site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Hammath Tiberias Synagogue
properties.description:
A site south of Tiberias where right next to a hot water spring a synagogue from the Byzantine period was found.
The site was excavated in the 1960's by M. Dothan, who exposed the beautiful mosaic floor of the syangogue that is exhibited at the site to this day.
To the north you can see clearly the modern days Spa installaion.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/hamat-tiberias

properties.name: Mt. Berenice / Church of the Anchor
properties.description:
Steep mountain south of Tiberias named after member of the family of king Herod. Excavations at the site by Y. Hirschfeld exposed various buildings, among them a Byzantine period church. In the center of the apse of the church a stone anchor was revealed. The anchor was probably venarated by Christian pilgrims in association to Jesus and / or his disciples.The site is not accesible to buses!.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/mount-berenice

properties.name: Ancient Tiberias
properties.description:
Under the hotels in the center of modern Tiberias lie the remains of ancient Tiberias, a city founded in the first century by Herod Antipas and named after the Roman emperor Tiberius. The city was an important Jeiwsh center in late antiquity, and an important fort during Crusader times.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ancient-tiberias

properties.name: Tiberias - Tomb site of Maimonides
properties.description:
Tomb site of Maimonides (Rambam), Jewish sage, phlisopher, and Physician.
Maimonides was born in Spain but in his youth his family escaped to north Africa beacuse of persecutions.
In Egypt Maimonides became known as a physician, and served the Visier of Egypt and his family.
He wrote many important books about the Jewish religious law (Halacha), such as "Hayad Hazakah", and "More Nevochim".
After his death his body was brought to Tiberias, and his tomb is a site of pilgrimage to this day.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tomb-of-maimonides

properties.name: Tiberias - The Mediavel Citadel
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ancient-tiberias

properties.name: Arbel Cliffs
properties.description:
Beautiful hike site near the Sea of Galilee. In antiquity Jewish and Druze rebeled seeked shelter in these cliffs, and to this day the fortifications from tth 18th century are visible.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Magadala / Migdal
properties.description:
Ancient site on the western shore of the sea of Galilee, famed to be the hometown of Mary Magdlane. Excavations conducted at the site in the 1930's, but today unfortunately, the site is closed to the public.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/migdal-magdala

properties.name: Gennesarath / "jesus boat"
properties.description:
Site mentioned in the New testament at the end of the event in which Jesus walked on the water (Mat. 14). In 1986 two members of Kibbutz Ginosar (named after the ancient site) found a sunken vessel on the shore. Excavation of the vessel showed that it was a fishing boat from the first century (!!!....). The vessel has been preserved and today is exhibited at the museum of the kibbutz.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/sea-of-galilee-boat

properties.name: Tabgha - Site of the Multiplication Miracle
properties.description:
A site west of Capernaum identified already in antiquity as the place where Jesus performed the miracle of the multiplication of the bread and fish (Mat 14:13-18).
Excavations at the site revealed remains of a Byzantine period church with beautiful mosaic floors, especially the one depicting scenes from the Nile.
A modern church built over the antiquities preserves impressivly the style of the ancient church.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/church-of-the-multiplication-of-loaves-and-fishes

properties.name: Tabgha - Peters' Primacy Church
properties.description:
A site west of Capernaum identified by Christian tradition as the place where Jesus appeared after his resurrection and appointed Peter to "Take care of my sheep" (John 4:16)The term "menza Christi" originates from the stone table in th church, where supposdly Jesus prepared fish for the desciples.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/church-of-the-primacy-of-peter

properties.name: Mount of Beatitudes
properties.description:
An octagonal churhc built on a hill west of Capernaum, where according to Christian tradition Jesus gave "the sermon on the mount" (Mat. 5-7).The site was built by the Franciscians in the 1930's and offer a beautiful view of the sea of Galilee.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/mount-of-beatitudes

properties.name: Kh. Jub Yousuf
properties.description:
A site in eastern Galilee, identified by a late Muslim tradition as the place where Joseph was thrown into a well (Genesis 37).
The site was a Khan in the Middle ages. It's remains can be seen left of the placemark.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Chorazim / Korazim
properties.description:
A Roman-Byzantine period Jewish village on a hill north of the Sea of Galilee, famed for being cursed by Jesus (Luke 10:13).
Excavations at the site revealed a Byzantine period synagogue.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/chorazin

properties.name: Capernaum / Cphar Nahum
properties.description:
Located on the the side of the road between Judaea and Syria, Capernaum ("The village of Nahum" in Hebrew), was a small village of fisherman some two thousand years ago, Yet it developed to a major pilgrimage site already in antiquity because of the time and miracles Jesus performed at the village.
Above the placemark (the white rectangular structure) is the ancient Synagogue.Below the placemark (The octagonal structure) is the church built over the presumed house of Peter, which indeed should have been right next to the synagogue (Mark 1:28).

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/capernaum

properties.name: `Araj / Masa'adeh / Bethsaida in Galilee?
properties.description:
'
A site on the bank of the Jordan river at its entrance to the Sea of Galilee.
Some scholars suggest this site is th port of Bethsaida. Others believe this is Bethsaida itself.
Surveyes at the site by M. Nun and B. Pixner revealed stone capitals and fragments of mosacis floors, all part of a large building.
B. Pixner suggest the site is "Bethsaida in the Galillee" metioned in John 12:21 as the home of Philip.
Indeed the Pilgrim Wilibald in 725 CE documents a visit to a church built in veneration of Philip in Bethsaida, yet at e-Tell such a church was never discovered.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/bethsaida

properties.name: e Tell / Bethsaida
properties.description:
A major archaeological site north of the sea of Galilee inhabitated in the Canaanite to Byzantine periods.
In 1838 E. Robinson was the first to identify the site with Biblical "Bethsaida"
Excavations at the site by R. Arav revealed impressive fortifications from Israelite period, and a rare stelae depiction a horned bull with a dagger.
The city thrived also in Roman period, when it was named "Julias". Remains from this period include houses winemaker and a fisherman.
As "Bethsaida" the site known from the New Testament as home town of Philip, Andrew, and Peter (John 1:44; 12:21); the site where Jesus healed a blind man (Mark 8:22); and the site cursed by Jesus (Luke 10:13).
Being 2 km away from the shore of the Sea of Galilee, some suggest the shore used to be at the banks of the site. Others suggest the port of the city was at 'Araj / Masa'adeh, 2.3 km SW of the site.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/bethsaida

properties.name: Tel Hadar
properties.description:
Biblical site on the eastern side of the Sea of Galilee. Excavations by M. Kokhavi revealed houses and walls from Israelite period, but the site became a holy Christian site after father B. Pixner identified the place to be the site of the SECOND miracle of the multiplication of the bread and fish.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kursi / the swine miracle
properties.description:
A site found by chance M. Nun while constructing a road in this area. Excavations at the site revealed a large monastic complex (above the placemark) and a cave with cross signs in its entrance (below the placemark). The site is believed to be the place where Jesus performed a miracle of removing an evil spirit into pigs (Mat. 8; Luke 8). Located in the "Land of the Gadarean" according to Matthew (8:28), go south to locate the ancient site of Gadara.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/kursi

properties.name: Ein Gev / Aphek?
properties.description:
In the center of Kibbutz Ein Gev lies an unnamed site from Canaanite and Israelite times. It was Excavated by a Japanesse expedition from the University of Tokyo, and most of the remains are well preserved and visible.
Some suggest this is the site of Aphek where Ahab the Israelite confronted Ben Hadad the Aramean (I Kings 20:26-30). Yet it seems that the site is too small to match the scene: "The rest of them escaped to the city of Aphek, where the wall collapsed on twenty-seven thousand of them.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Hippos-Sussita
properties.description:
Greko-Roman site founded by Pompeii in the first century BCE. It was member of the Decapolis, (a treaty of ten cities, a term mentioned also in the New Testament.) Large scale excavation are carried out at the site in recent years by A. Segal on behalf of the University of Haifa.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/sussita

properties.name: Tel Soreg / Aphek?
properties.description:
A site on the western slopes of the Golan highets. Survey of the site revealed evidence for occupation during Canaanite and Israelite periods.
D. Ben Ami suggest the site is Biblical "Aphek", the place of the battle between Ahab king of Israel and Ben Hadad the Aramean (I Kings 20:26-30). The name of the site is preserved at Arab village PIQ, 3 km E of the site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Piq / Aphek?
properties.description:
An ancient site on the Golan highets, suggested by many scholars to be the site of the battle between Ahab and Ben Hadad (I Kings 20:26-30). However survey at the site did not reveal any evidence for occupation of the site during the Iron age.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. Kanaf
properties.description:
An ancient site on the Golan heights where remains of a Talmudic period Synagogue were found.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Deir Aziz
properties.description:
An ancient site on the Golan heights where remains of a Talmudic period Synagogue were revealed.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Umm el-Qanatir
properties.description:
A site in the golan where ongoing excavation by Haim ben-David are revealing and restoring a synagogue from the Byzantine period.
Left of the placemark you can see the large rectangular structure of the synagogue.
Right of the placemark is a set of springs channeled into an ancient set of pools.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Gamla / Gamala
properties.description:
Ancient Jewish site in the Golan heights famous for the struggle of its inhabitants against the Romans, which became a symbol for Jewish Heroizm.Excavations at the site in the 1970's by S. Gutman exposed the wall of the city, with the dramatic evidence of the Roman siege and penetration point into the city. In the city a Synagogues from the 1st century was found. Excavations resumed in the 1990's by D. Syon.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/gamla

properties.name: Deir Karuch
properties.description:
An ancient site on the Golan Heights where well preserved remains of a Byzantine period monastery remains were found.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/gamla

properties.name: Rujum el-Hiri
properties.description:
The Israeli version of Stonehenge!!
A Third Millenia BCE mysterious site in the Golan heights, whose Arabic name means "Ruins oif the wild Cat"
Perhaps was a tomb, but buit in connection to astronomy. It is tempting to associate the site to the Canannite "Giants", and especially to "Og king of the Bashan" (Deut. 3:11)

Frankly the site looks much better from Google earth then from the ground...
And if you do insist to reach the site from the ground, make sure not to get off tracks - many mine fields in the area!!..

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tel-dor

properties.name: Bethlehem in the Galilee
properties.description:
Possibly the location where Jesus was born?
Long ago scholars have expressed doubts weather Jesus was really born in Bethlehem in Judaea, some 110 km south of Nazareth (See for example article here (http://bib-arch.org/nativity/bswbNativitySubPage.asp?PubID=BSBR&Volume=16&Issue=1&ArticleID=11)).
Excavations held here in the years 1998-2003 by the IAA revealed also remains of a first century CE Jewish village. Though no remains of a maternity ward were discovered in these excavations, archaeologist A. Oshri suggests that here, and not in Bethlehem in Judaea, Jesus was born.
The transition of the birth of Jesus from here to Bethlehem in Judaea, according to this theory, was done for one important reason - to link the origin of Jesus with the origin of a nother famous figure from Biblical times - King David.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Nazareth - The Synagogue Church
properties.description:
Sounds like an oxymoron, but indeed this is traditional site of the ancient synagogue of Nazareth, which was turned into a church, but in order to venarate the ancient synagogue...
From an archaeological perspective there are no finds at the site to support the possibility the an ancient synagogue was indeed at the site.

For more information about the site:

properties.name: Tiberias - St. Peter's church
properties.description:
A Franciscian church in the center of modern Tiberias, sanctifies the event which ended with Jesus ordering Peter: "from now on you will catch men"(Luke 5:11).
The city does not play a major role in the stories of Jesus and his disciples, but the crusaders located here the third appearance of Jesus after his resurrection, since it happened "near the sea of Tiberias" (John 21:1), however the location of this event has "moved" in modern times to st. peter's primacy church, near Capernaum.

For more information about the site:

properties.name: "Adithaim"?
properties.description:
A large site uncovered in a survey and salvage excavation for the construction of road 444. 
The site included a big (60x48 m) fortress in time of the Hasmoneans.
This may have been "Hadid" which was well fortified by Simon the Maccabee (I Has. 12:38; Ant. 13:203).
Its name "Aditaim" in Joshua 15:36, Eusebius and Madaba map suggest it was actually intwo locations, perhaps one at Tel Hadid, and one here. 
Sadly the WHOLE site was cleared for the construction of the road (!).

For more details about the site:
http://www.antiquities.org.il/site_Item_heb.asp?id=117
Dahari U. 1999, ‘Adithaim now Aditha and Betomelgezis in the Madaba Map’, in: The Madaba Map Centenary (1897-1997) Travelling Through the Byzantine Umayyad Period, eds. Michele Piccirillo and Eugenio Alliata, Stadium Biblicum Franciscanum, Collectio Maior 40, pp. 246-248.

properties.description: A site that is by Muslim tradition the burial place of Joshua (contra Jodges 2:8).

properties.name: Hyrcania - closest parking spot
properties.description: A Green marked trail from Hyrcania valley main road reaches this spot

properties.name: Anjarah Lady of the Mount Monastery
properties.description: By local Christian tradition a site where the holy family rested during their flight from King Herod.

properties.name: Al Rama
properties.description:
A site whose name is preserving the biblical site "Beit Haram" (Number 32:34-36; Joshua 13:27). According to Josephus the site was renames "Julias" by Herod Antipas and fortified (Wars 2 9 1). Later, under its other name ("Livias") the site is mentioned by several Byzantine period pilgrims. Some of them mention healing baths at the site ("the Baths of Moses").
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Qasr Bshir
properties.description: Well Preserved Roman Fort. Part of the Limes Arabicus

properties.name: Al Azraq Fort
properties.description: "The Blue Fort". One of the forts along the 'Limes Arabicus'. Placed next to a rare oasis. Used also as a base by T.E. Lawrence.

properties.name: Qasr eth-Thuraiya
properties.description: Fort along the Limes Arabicus

properties.name: Qasr el-al
properties.description: Roman Fort along the Limes Arabicus

properties.name: Tell al Abu-Kharaz / Jabesh Gilead?
properties.description: Excavated by a Swedish Archaeological Expedition bwteen the years 1989-2001, under the direction of Peter M. Fisher, it is suggested to be identified with biblical Jabesh Gilead. If indeed so, it is the place where Saul and his sons were buried.

properties.name: 'Ara'ir
properties.description: Biblical site built by the people of Gad (Numbers 32:34). Later part of the lot of Reuben (Deut. 2:36, 3:12, Jos. 12:2, 4:48, 13:9, 16). Mentioned in the David's time (II Sam. 24:5, II Chr. 11:44). Mesha stele indicates he ruled it, but later it was attacked by HAzael king of Aram (II kings 10:33). Mentioned also in II Chr. 5:8, 17 and Jer. 48:19.  Excavations yielded finds from the Bronze, Iron and Nabatean times.

properties.name: Tell Edh-Dahab al-Sharqi / Penuel?
properties.description: A site 8 km east of Deir Alla and 1 km from possible Mahanaim. Might be the site of Penuel. Penuel is first mentioned in the bible as named by Jacob after wrestling Gods' angel (Genesis 32:22-32). Later the people of Penuel did not feed Gideon army. In return he killed its people and knocked down its tower (Judges 8:17). Later Jerobam moved his capital from Shechem to Penuel and fortified it. His succesor, Ba'asha, moved the capital to Tirzah. Penual is also mentioned in Shishaq's campaign. The site has not been excavated yet as far as I know

properties.name: Crossing point of the Yabok (Wadi Zarka)
properties.description: The Crossing point of the Yabok, between Mahanaim and Penuel. If indeed so, this is the site where Jacob wrestled against God's angel, and later his name was changed from Jacob to Israel (Genesis 32).

properties.name: Tell Edh-Dahab al Gharbi / Mahanim? / Amathus?
properties.description: An Archaeological site along the strategic path from the Moab plateau to the Jordan river and pass. According to Genesis 32:2 Jacob camped here. Later Ishba'al son of Saul was crowned here (II Samuel 2 8), and later David fled to here from his son Abshalom (II Samuel  17:24). "Mahanaim" is also mentioned in Shishaq campaign. Archaeological excvateions at the site yielded find from Iron Age II including cultic figurnes, suggesting it was a cultic center (as its neighboring names' site suggest - Penuel). The excavations yielded also finds from Hellenistic and Herodian times, and so some suggest this is the site of Classical periods Amathus.

properties.name: Castellum Belvoir / Kastel
properties.description: A Crusaders period fortress built to protect the road to Jerusalem. Named later "Kastel", in 1948 it was the site of pivotal events in the Israeli-Arab war.

properties.name: Motza Temple Site
properties.description: A site discovered in the 2012 during salvage excavation prior to constructing a new bridge. The finds date to the early Israelite period, and inlclude evidence of a temple. in 2017 Prof. Ne'eman suggested that perhaps this is "Beit Oved Edom Hagiti", where the ark was placed for three months. For more about this site: http://dannythedigger.com/motza-temple

properties.name: 9/11 Living Memorial Plaza
properties.description: A memorial inaugarated in 2009 commemorating the victims of September 11th terror attack in the USA. For more about this site:   https://dannythedigger.com/9-11-jerusalem-memomrial-monument

properties.name: Tell el-Hesi
properties.description: A significant site in the field of Biblical Archaeology. After Conder proposed to identify it with Biblical LAchish the site was excavated by Petrie in the 1890. He failed in his identification by laid the foundations of Biblical archaeology research, i.e. pttery typology and stratigarphy. The site was excavated again by Bliss in 1891, and ASOR in the 1970s.

properties.name: Hesi Springs
properties.description: In 1838 Robinson proposed that these are the springs where Philip baptized the Ethiopian Eunuch. While most sources and scholars suggest it happened in Ein el-Dirwah or Ein Haniyeh, the description of the pilgrim from Placenzia implies it should be traced between Eleuthropolis / Beit-Guvrin and Beer-Sheva (33)

properties.name: Ein Nashut Ancient Synagogue
properties.description: Reviewed first by Schumacher as "Deir Rachib", Ein Nasut proved to bear remains of a 5th century Synagogue. Entered from the south, it bears the same entry concept as in Capernaum.

properties.name: Dvora Ancient Synagogue
properties.description: A Syrian village surveyed after the Six Day War and proved to bear remains of a Byzantine period ornamented Synagogue, including a significant inscription identifing the Beit Hamidrash of Rabbi Elazar Hakapar".

properties.name: Kh. Ibn Nasser / Schechem's Gilgal?
properties.description: A hilltop 2 km east of biblical Schechem (Tel Balata), documented by the PEF in the 19th CEN as "Kh. Guligil", and said to bear remains from early Iron age. Being so, some scholars suggest to track here the "Gilgal" mentioned in Deut. 11:30: "near the great trees of Moreh, in the territory of those Canaanites living in the Arabah in the vicinity of Gilgal."

properties.name: Gilgal Binyamin?
properties.description: A footshaped site discovered in 2013. Suggest to be one of the biblical "Gilgal" sites. closest coordinates - N 31 54 17 E 35 20 8

properties.name: Wadi el-Yabis - Nahal Chrit?
properties.description: Said to be where Elijah hid and provide by ravens. "Charoth" in the Byzantine Period. The Jordanians recently renamed it from "Wadi el-Yabis" (=the dry reiverbed") to Wadi Riyan (="The Saturated river").

properties.name: תל אל מקברה
properties.description: ל קטן (מידותיו 25X40 בערך דונם, ) בחודש דצמבר סייר במקום נלסון גליק (גליק תש"ך 210) והתארח אצל משפ ערב א-זינאת, בסיור בתל הוא מצא שברי חרסים רבים מכל המינים, ורבים מהם מהתקופה הישראלית (ברזל 1+2 המאה ה-13 עד ה-6 לפנה"ס) כמה מאות מטרים ממזרח נמצאת גבעה שטוחח תל אבו אל חרז (תל אבי החרוזים) גם שם מוצא גליק חרסים ובכמות גדולה יותר גם כן מהתקופה הישראלית, וכן בית ארבעת המרחבים המתוארך לתקופת המלוכה, מגבעה זו של תל אבו אל חרז, נשקף היטב תל אל חצ'ן היא בית שאן, ולכן מציע גליק לזהות בתל אל חרז ובתל אל מקברה את העיר יבש גלעד המקראית.

properties.name: תל צליחאת
properties.description: Albright suggests to identify this site with biblical "Zartan"

properties.name: Swemeh
properties.description:
A village whose Arabic name is possibly preserving the biblical name of "Beit Yesimot". According to Numbers 33:49 Before crossing the Jordan, the Isrealites camped between "Beit Yesimot" and "Abel Sitim" (the latter is identified at Teleliat el Ghassul or Tel el Hammam).
"Beit Yesimot" is also mentioned in Joshua 13:20, Ezekiel 25:9. It is also mentioned by Josephus and Eusebius as "Isimot". According to Josephus during the Great Jewish rebellion Jews fled to this site.
www.Dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Teleliat el-Ghassul
properties.description:
A cluster of small mounds excavated in the 1920s by an expedition from the Pontifical institute in Jerusalem speculating this is Sodom and/or Gomorrah.
The excavation yielded a site rich in finds that was in habited throughout the Neolithic period, as well as a subsequent period which was labeled as the "Chalcolithic period". The site is famous for its prehistoric murals, which are stored at the Rockefeller Museum.
www.dannythedigger.com/

properties.name: Tell Nimrim / Beit Nimrah?
properties.description:
A site said to be in the lot of the tribe of Gad (Number 32:34-36; Joshua 13:27). Under the name "Beit Nimrim" also mentiond in Isaiah 15:6 and Jeremiah 38:34. Under the "Bethnabaris" Josephus records in detail its brutal conquest by the Romans (Wars 4 4 4-6). As "Beit Nimron" the site is also mentioned in the Talmud. Eusebius calls it "Beithnabris". According to Glueck in the EB age Beit Nimrah was in Tell esh-Mustah; in the Iron age it was at Tell Blaibil; and in the Classical periods it was here, at Tell Nimrim/ Bethanabaris.
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tell Blaibil / Beit Nimrah?
properties.description: Archaeological site suggested to be Beit-Nimrah during the Iron Age.

properties.name: Tell esh-Mustach
properties.description: Accoding to S. Collins this is the possible location of "Admah"

properties.name: "Yehosef son Caiaphas" Tomb
properties.description: The spot where the tomb of the high priest Caiaphas was discovered. The remains of the tomb are all covered today, but there is a green pipeline over the cave, to "diffuse the impurity of the tomb"..

properties.name: Talpiot Tomb
properties.description: The back of Dov Gruner 22. Here in 1980 a Kokhom tomb was discovered. in 2007 a TV show argued it could be the tomb of Jesus and his family. The cave is not accesible and is covered by concrete.

properties.name: Khirbet Beit-Mizza / Emmaus?
properties.description: Ruins of an Ottoman era village north of Motza. Some scholars suggest to locate here the Emmaus mentioned in Luke 24:13

properties.name: Traces of the Roman Road from Jerusalem to Emmaus
Church of Bishop Malchios
properties.description: From early 6th century CE

properties.name: Western Church
properties.description: Bears an inscription from 603 CE

properties.name: Station 1
properties.description:
The "church of condemnation" at this spot marks the supposed location of the trial of Jesus. It is over the place of the Antonia fortress, which king Herod built to monitor the Temple mount.
From here begins the famous "Via Dolorosa" to the site of the Holy Sepulchre.
Some scholars are of the opinion that the trial really took place at Herods' palace, near Jaffa gate.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Station 2
properties.description:
The "Church of Flagellation" at this spot marks the supposed location where Jesus was flogged by the Romans after his trial. Roman period street floor at the place attests to antiquity of the site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Station 3
properties.description:
A chapell on the side of the street marks the spot were supposdly Jesus fell from the weight of the cross for the first time. Only occasionaly it is open to the public.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Station 4
properties.description:
A Mark on the wall on the eastern side of the street indicates that here, according to the local tradition, Mary saw Jesus as he was carrying the cross on his back, walking towards the crucifixion site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Station 5
properties.description:
A chapell on the corner of the "Via Dolorosa" street marks the supposed spot where according to Gospels Simon of Cyrene helped Jesus to carry the Cross (Mat. 27:32).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Station 6
properties.description:
A mark on a pillar engaged to the wall indicates here, according to Christian tradition, a woman named Veronica wiped the face of Jesus, and doing so she created a VERA ICON ("a true image") of his face in the napkin. Some scholars argue that perhaps her name (Veronica) derives from her act (creating a Vera Icon).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Station 7
properties.description:
A Chapell on the junction of the two street marks the supposed location where Jesus fell from the weight of the Cross for the second time.A pillar from the Byzantine period CARDO can be seen at the site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Station 8
properties.description:
A mark on the wall on the side of the street marks the supposed location where the women of Jerusalem saw Jesus and cried for him (Luke 23:27).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Station 9
properties.description:
A pillar on the top of the Holy Sepulchre marks the supposed spot where Jesus fell from the weight of the cross for the third time. Right next to it is a coptic church, which only a few know that it leads to a Byzantine period undergraound huge water reservoir.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Stations 10-14
properties.description:
The last five stations of the "Via Dolorosa" are with in the Holy Sepulchre complex. below the placemark is the Golgotha, the crucifixion site. Right of the placemark, the clearly visible round dome marks the spot where Jesus was buried, and resurrected, according to Christian belief.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/holy-sepulchre

properties.name: Kh. Feinan - Punon
properties.description:
Kh. Feinan site bears a mass of ancient shafts created in antiquity in search of Copper.
The first people to extract copoper at the site were from the Neolithic Period (7th-th Mill. BCE). In The Chalcolithic period (4th mill. BCE) the first smelting furnaces were used at the site, turning the copper was turned into tools.
The shafts were made mostle during the Early Bronze age and the Iron Age.
In The Roman period the search for copper at the site was re-newed, though mostly in the exisiting shafts.
Most remarkable from this period is the fortress added on the north bank of Wadi Guwair.
During the Byzantine period two church were built at the site, and the place was known by the name PHAINO.
The site is undoubltfuly Biblical Punon mentioned as one of the stops along the sojourn of the Israelites from Egypt to the promised land (Numbers 33:42-43).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. es-Nahas - Ir Nahash
properties.description:
A Biblical period site on the eastern side of the Aravah, where 90 copper quarring shaft were documented. At the smelting site a square fortress was found, which is clearly visible thru GE, and even its two chambers gate.
The Site is identified with Biblical "Ir Nahash" mentioned in II Chr. 4:12.
The site was recently excavated by T.E. Levy and M. Najjar, and proved to be from the Iron age I, i.e. the time of Solomon!. Therefore the Biblical quote in II Chr. 4:17: “In the plain of the Jordan the king [Solomon] cast them [the copper utensils], in the clay ground between Succoth and Zeredah" , is perhaps refereing to this site (!!).
For recent publication of research at the site see: T.E.Levy and M. Najjar. 2006. Edom and Copper. BAR 32[4]:24-35, 70.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Lot's cave
properties.description:
Holy site where according to Christian tradition Lot settled after the destruction of Soddom and Gomorrah. In the Byzantine Period a monastic complex was built at the site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. et-Tannur
properties.description:
A Nabatean shrine located on an isolated hill, but not far from the "kings highway".
Excavations at the site by N. Glueck in the 1930's revealed a richly decorated edifice, including a rare depiction of the Zodiac.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Sodom? / Bab edh Drah
properties.description:
Big site on the eastern side of the Dead Sea that dates to the third millenia BCE. Below the placemark you can clearly see the wall of the site. All around the site there is a HUGE necropolis, rich in finds.Some scholars argue that Bab edh-Drad and kh. Numeira (further south) are no other then Sodom and Gomorrah.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Gomorrah? / Numeira
properties.description:
A site on the eastern side of the Dead Sea from the third Millenia BCE. The date of the site could indicate this is Biblical Gomorrah, whose name is perhaps preserved in the modern Arabic name of the site - Numeira (!!!).Accoridingly Sodom perhaps should be located 13 km to the north, at Bab edh-Dhra.

Both suggestions are very loose, as most Biblical Scholars are of the opinion the story is fictional, not factual. However the story could also be etymological, i.e. the ruins of these sites inspired a folk tradition during the Biblical peiod that the sites were destroyed by the wrath of God.
For a suggestion to locate all the five cities mentioned Genesis 14:2, see BAR 6\5 (1980):26-36.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Mt. Nebo
properties.description:
Traditional Burial site of Moses, on the eastern side of the riverJordan. Byzantine period churches revealed at the size bear a rich set of mosaic floors.

For more information about the Site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Madaba
properties.description:
Madaba was a member of the Decapolis, but is more famous for the amazing sixth century mosaic map found while renovating a church in the late 19th century CE. It attempts to document various sites in the Holy Land. There should be also an archaeological museum, opened in 1979.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Madaba - Map Mosaic Floor
properties.description:
Madaba was a member of the Decapolis, but is more famous for the amazing sixth century mosaic map found while renovating a church in the late 19th century CE. The map is the spirutal ancestor of Google Earth (!!!!), as it attempts to document various sites in the Holy Land.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Machaerus/ Macherous/ Michvar
properties.description:
An ancient fortfied Hilltop on the eastern side of the Jordan Valley overlooking the Dead Sea. It was first developed by the Hasmonean kings in the first century BCE and again by king Herod "the Great" during his reign (37-4 BCE).The site is most famous for being the place of the imprisonment and execution of John the Baptist (Luke 9:7-9; Mat. 14:1-12; Mk. 6:14-29; Jos. ant. 18.5.2.).After its destrcution by the Romans in 72 CE the hilltop was never settled again. The Arab village east of the mountain top preserved its name (Mukawir), and so it was identified already early in the 19th century. Excavations of German, American, and Franciscan expeditions at the site over the 1960's to 1990's revealed the fortified palace on the "upper city", parts of the "lower city", and elements of the ancient water system. .

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Hammamat Ma'in hot springs
properties.description:
Site SW of Madaba famous for it's thermal mineral hot springs and waterfalls. Josephus describes it in Wars 7:180-189 as having cold and warm springs, and a root good against demons ("Baaras").

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Hisban / Heshbon
properties.description:
Antiquities site in Jordan, whose Biblical name (Heshbon) has been preserved to this day.According to Num. 21:21-30 the city was ruled by S ihon the Emorite. Later it was inhabited by the tribe of Reuben and Gad (Jos. 13:15-28).
Herod the great settled soldiers at the site (Ant. 15:294), yet it was destroyed at the outbreak of the Jewish rebelion against the Romans (Wars 2:458).
But the city recovered, and in the days of the emperor Elgabal (218-222) it was even ranked "polis" and was granted to mint its own coins.
In the Byzantine period it had and Episcopal seat, and it was inhabited under Muslim rule until the 13th century CE.
Excavations at Hisban were conducted by a few expeditions between the years 1968 to 1978. The excavated areas can be clearly seen from this aerial view.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tyre
properties.description:
Tyre (Hebrew - Tsor), has a long and rich history.
Hiram king of Tyre provided timber and artisans for the construction of Solomons' temple in Jerusalem (I Kings 5).
Nebuchanezzar failed to conquer the city, and Alexander the great succeded only after filling the causeway to the island from the main land (To this day the nighborhood built on the causeway is called el-raml - "sand").
According to the NT Jesus healed in the area of the city a Canaanite girl who was possesed by a demon (Mat. 15:21-28).
The city thrived under Roman rule. Above the placemark you can clearly see the colonnade of the city's agora. The remains of the rectangular structure below the placemark are probably of the city's palaestra.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tyre - Hippodrome
properties.description:
The Hippdrome of Tyre was constructed during the Roman period, probably in the second cnetury CE.
The aerial view shows clearly the fence in the middle of the racing track (Matae), and the reconstructed seats near the 180' turning point at the southern end of the hippodrome.
The hippodrome abutts the main street of the city at its northern edge. The aerial view shows clearly a few reconstructed pillars along that road.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Sidon Jewish Cemetery
properties.description:
At this placemark Jewish tombstones attest this area was a Jewish graveyard, which was in use until the 20th century.
I'd like to thank Mr. Hussein from Sidon for drawing my attention to this placemark. Peace on to you Mr. Hussein!.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Sidon - Sea Castle
properties.description:
Sidon has a long and rich history. The ancient city was built on a promontory facing an island, which sheltered vessels from storms and attacks from the mainland.
The Persians made Sidon a major port, and built in the city a royal park, as well as a temple for Eshmun.
The city was also known then for its glass and purple dyed textiles.
During the Hellenistic period Sidon was known as a sports center, and it competitions drew athletes from all the region.
The city continued to thrive under Roman and Byzantine rule (64BCE-636 CE).
Under Frankish rule, the city became the chief town of the Seigniory of Sagette and the second and the four baronies of the Kingdom of Jerusalem. Above the placemark the remains of the Crusaders' period castle are visible.
Yet the archaeological remains in Sidon today are scarce, as they were looted systematically since the 19th century. Furhtermore dense modern construction prevents any future excavations in city.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Sidon - Murex Hill
properties.description:
At this spot in Sidon many remains of Murex shells can be found. These shells were used by the phoenicians to produce purple-dyed textiles, which were very vaulable, and became a symbol of royalty.

I'd like to thank Rolf Haubrichs for aiding me on this post. for the location in a publication made by him go here (http://www.mtsn.tn.it/pubblicazioni/7/40-1/133-160_Haubrichs.pdf).

I'd also like to thank Mr. Hussein from Sidon for varifing the exact location of the post!. Peace on to you, Mr. Hussein!.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Heliopolis / Baalbek - Main Temple
properties.description:
One of the best preserved shrine complexes from the Roman period. The place mark is at the court of the temple to Jupiter. below it (=to its south) is the temple of Bacchus, and SE of it is the round temple of Venus. On the hill South of this complex was the temple of Merkury. My numismatic research suggests that the Roman cult at the site originated in a similar Iturean cult. See INJ 13(2000-2002):85-93.
www.dannythedigger.com‏‏

properties.name: Hatzevah
properties.description:
Ancient site on the road from the Dead Sea to Eilat. Identified as Biblical TAMAR, the site was fortified by Solomon (I Kings 9 18-19). The site continued to be used in the Roman period, probably by the Nabateans, and later by the Romans themselves. Excavations at the site revealed a unique favissa of Edomite idols (exactly where the placemark is!). The idols are exhibited today at the Israel Museum.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

ואיתות. תצפית יפה למרחב.

properties.name: Rujum Tsafir
properties.description:
בבסיס מעלה העקרבים, ממקומת מצודה רבועה (9.10 X 9.35 מ'). ממערב לה מבנה מלבני בן חמשה חדרים. הממצא בשני המבנים מלמד שהם שמשו במאה השלישית-רביעית לסה"נ.מרוגם צפיר מתחיל "מעלה העקרבים" )סימון שבילים כחול(. זהו ציר המתגבר על הפרשי גובה של 430 מ' על פני כ3 ק"מ. במיוחד חריף השיפוע בחלקו התחתון, שם יש להתגבר על הפרשי גובה של 350 מ' על פני 1940 מ'. ציר זה נסקר ע"י חוקרים שונים, ונמדד ע"י מ' הראל ב1957. הציר נקבע כך שאף שהשיפוע הממוצע של המתלול הוא 36 % הציר ברובו אינו עולה על 18%. מיתון השיפוע הושג ע"י יצירת פיתולים רבים בציר, לעיתים נבנו קירות תמך כדי גובה 3 מ' לתמוך בציר. רוחבו הממוצע של הציר הוא 2 מ', ובמקומות רבים נחצבו מדרגות להקל על התנועה.ההשקעה הרבה בקביעת הציר, ובעיקר חציבת המדרגות, היא תכונה שאינה אופינית לצירי התנועה הנבטים, אך כן מוכרת בתרבות הרומית. יש להניח שהציר הותקן יחד עם המצודות לאורכו, קרי במאה השלישית לסה"נ.השם "מעלה העקרבים" מקורו מן המקרא: "ונסב לכם הגבול מנגב למעלה עקרבים ועבר צנה והיה תוצאותיו מנגב לקדש ברנע.." )במדבר לד 4, דומה ביהושוע טו 3(, וכן: "וגבול האמורי ממעלה עקרבים מהסלע ומעלה")שופטים א 36(.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com‎‎

properties.name: Khirbet Tsafir
properties.description:
נמצאת באמצע הדרך של "מעלה העקרבים". תבניתה מצודה רבועה (9X9 מ'). שרידי גרם מדרגות ושפכי המפולות מעידים כי למבנה היתה קומה שניה. המצד מוקף חצר רבועה (20 X20 מ') ובו הובחנו שלוש מכלאות. הממצא כולו מהמאה השלישית-רביעית לסה"נ. מדרום-מזרח למצד שרידי סכר לאגירת מי שטפונות בערוץ מקומי. הסכר השתמר לגובה 5 מ' )!(.

properties.name: Scorpions Ascent
properties.description:
An acient ascent in the Negev, perhaps the one from Biblical times (Joshua 15:3).
In the Roman period many steps were carved in the path of the ascent, probably to improve the traffic of the Camel caravans.
Three fortresses were constructed along the ascent, to protect and serve its users. The placemark is where some of the curves are visible even from space..
To your right, on the northern ridge, you can see much more clearly the asphalt modern road by the same name. Many mistakenly think the paved road over the road from Biblical times.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Metsad Tsafir
properties.description:
מצד עתיק הנמצא בקצהו העליון של "מעלה העקרבים", על גבעה שלטת. מכיל ארבע מבנים. בדרומו מצודה רבועה עם גרם מדרגות לקומה שניה. הממצא מהמאה השלישית-רביעית לסה"נ. ממערב למצודה מבנה מלבני ובתוכו חלוקה לארבעה חדרים. מבנה זה נסמך למבנה מלבני שכנראה קדם, ויתכן כי פורק ויצא מכלל שימוש כאשר נבנתה המצודה. כ100 מ' מצפון לשני מבנים אלו נתגלו בסיסי שני מבנים נוספים, מתקופת המקרא. כ200 מ' מצפון-מערב למצודה נבנה סכר לאגירת מי שטפונות בואדי הסמוך.ממצד צפיר ניתן להמשיך צפונה בסימון שבילים שחור עד לכביש מצפון, או בסימון שבילים אדום לכביש ממזרח. או בסימון שבילים כחול לנחל חתירה, ובנחל חתירה (סימון שבילים ירוק). למצד עין ירקעם. ציר עובר דרך מעלה הפלמ"ח.


For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com‎

Was abandoned after the Muslim conquest of the land.Much of the site was excavated by A. Negev in the 1960's. He revealed two churches, a bath-house, stables, a cemetary, and spacious houses. In one of them a hoard of 10,555 silver coins was found, all dating to the 3rd century.Near the site ancient damns attest to the way the inhabitants of the site collected water.

Next to the "two tablets" petroglyph are two more images.. I believe they are all connected, and connected to the Bible..

The site is today unattented, but as you can see ,even from space(..), the trees continue to blossom.
A similar farm was created also at Shivtah.

East of the city of Avdat A. Negev found evidence for what he believes is a workshop where Nabatean pottery was produced.
Nabatean pottery is known for it's thin ("egg shell") painted ware in various forms, but especially bowls. New research is suggesting it is really an oven for making bread for the nearby military base.

Scholars argue if it was used by the Nabateans, or by the Romans after the annexation of the Nabatean to the Roman Empire.

properties.name: Mysterious "Desert kite" !
properties.description:
A fine example of a "desert kite" that can actually be seen better from space then from the ground... Look how the two lines on both sides of the place mark meet at the dry river bed, creating a mysterious triangular shape (!). What is it???The first "desert kites" were documented by WWI British pilots flying over arid areas in northern Africa. These sites are apperently prehistoric animal traps. A "desert kite" Graffiti found in Jordan bears the name SHAHAT, a term known also from the Bible to mean a trap.

properties.name: As Sala' / Biblical Sela?
properties.description: Unlike the common assumption, biblical scholars believe biblical Sela is here, not in Petra. The main biblical account records how Amaziah conquered Sela and renmaed it Yekotel (II kings 14:7; 2 Chr. 25:12). The site has not been yet excavated but surveys uncovered remains of EB to Nabatean Period. It was mostly settled in the Iron age, when it was the capital of the Edomites. It is also known for the Nabonidus Inscription engraved in one of its rocks.                  De Riva R. 2019. Dangling Asssyriology BAR 45/6:25-32.

properties.name: Taphila / Biblical Tophel?
properties.description: Regional center. Possibly the location of "Tophel" mentioned only once in the bible, in Deut. 1:1)

properties.name: Basira / Biblical Bozrah
properties.description: Homeland of Esau and the The edomite king Jacob Ben Zerah (Gen. 36: 32-33). Amos (1:12), Isaiah (34:6) and Jremiah 49:13) all prophecized its destruction  - and they were right! Excavations at the site in the 1970s indicated it was settled in the 8th-7th century BCE (Levant 6; LEvant 24). Excavations in 2009 also uncovered a Byzantine Period Church. The local Muslim perfrom populat annual pilgrimage to the tomb of Al-Harith Bin Umair Al-Azadi, whose murder in 639 CE led to the battle of Mu'tah.

properties.name: Ain Salem / Aenon near Salim?
properties.description: https://www.academia.edu/36194684/THE_DISCOVERY_OF_AENON_SALEEM_NEAR_SITE_OF_JESUS_BAPTISM                                                                                                                                                https://www.researchgate.net/figure/A-map-showing-Ain-Salem-and-the-surrounding-zone-1Tell-Iktano-2-Tell-EL-Husan-3_fig2_351979649

properties.name: Lot's Wife Salt Statue
properties.description: Incuding two man kissing next to her.. by local tradition they are reflecting Genesis 19:5, and the reason why Sodom and Gomorrah were destoryed.

properties.name: KH. Qazone
properties.description: A site where Politis uncovered evidence of over 3500 tombs similiar to the ones in Qumran.

properties.name: Cemetery of ancient Zoar
properties.description: Cemetery of Zoar from the Roman-Byzantine period. Tombstones found here attest to a vibrant Jewish community in the Roman-Byzantine period. Some bear a count to the destruction of the temple.

properties.name: Kh. Sheikh Issa Wanak / Ancient Zoar?
Tawain as-Sukkar / Qasr a Tov
properties.description: Mamluk era sugar plant

properties.name: Mazra'a
properties.description: Possible home of "Basas son of Yshua" mentioned in the Babta archive. He was a witness in one of Babta's dates sale, and later, with "Julia" he sued Babtha on properties she inherited from her second husband (Ketushion) in "Mechoza". There is a nother document in which Babtha sued Miriam, Ketushion's second wife, for confiscating the husband's properties. The verdict of both was not found..

properties.name: Ma'in / Ba'al Ma'on / Belemounta
properties.description:
According to Number 32:38 was a Moabite city.
Became in the lot of the tribe of Reuben (Number 33:3, 37-38; 1 Chr. 5:8).
Mentioned in the Mesha stele at "Baal Maon", and by Jeremiah at "Beit Maon" (48:23).
In 1973 A mosaic floor of a church was found SW of Ma'in. Dating to 719 CE it is now in the Madaba archaeological museum. It is famous for depicting 11 sites - [Charach M]uba - Karak; Areopolis - Rabbah; Gadoron - Es-Salt; Esbun[ta] - Hesban; and Belemunta - Ma'in.

properties.name: Umm er Rasas
properties.description:
A beautiful Mosaic floor that depicts "Decapolis" cities.

For more information about the Site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Araq el-Amir
properties.description:
Hellenistic period palace, well preserved to this day (Just look at the image of the rectangular building!!, and this is a view from space!!!).The palace was probably of Hyracnus of the family of Tobias, a Jewish tax collector.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: "Bethany Beyond the Jordan"
properties.description:
A site on the eastern bank of the Jordan river preserving the tradition of the location where John baptised Jesus (John 1:28).To the right of the placemark is the recently completed Greek-Orthodox church, and above the placemark is the wooden deck built to enable pilgrims to immerse in the Jordan River. The Hashemite kingdom of Jordan also installed baptism pools further to the west. More ancient remains related to baptism were discovered along wadi Kharrar by the Jordanian archaeologist M. Waheeb.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: "John the Baptist" church
properties.description:
The remains of a large church comlex discovered at this placemark are perhaps the remains of a monastery from the Byzantine period which was dedicated to John the Baptist. 

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Ancient Baptising site
properties.description:
A bit east of the current flow of the Jordan River, Jordanian archaeologist M. Waheeb discovered a large church, a chapel and a stepped paved path descending to the level of the Jordan river. Although no water passes here today, It is believed that in antiquity the Jordan river, or part of it, passed at the bottom of the stepped path, and so pilgrim could baptised at this location. 

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: "Elijah's Hill"
properties.description:
A small hill along Wadi Kharrar is identified by a local tradition as the site from which Elijha ascended to heaven (II Kings 2:11). Excavations at the site revealed a set of at least four churches from the Byzantine period. One of the churches was built against a cave carved in the side of the hill. This cave was probably venerated in antiquity as the dwelling cave of John the Paptist. The site also bears a set of stepped pools and aquaducts who provided water from nearby springs. It is presumed that the site provided baptising services for pilgrims in the Byzantine period. These poilgrims probably believed John the Baptist himself baptised in the very same spot.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Saphsaphas Monastery?
properties.description:
A set of caves carved on the side of Wadi Kharrar are perhaps the remains of Byzantine period Laura monastery named "Saphasaphas" mentioned in the writings of John Moschus. 

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.description:
For more information about the site:

properties.name: Tell Kafrein / Gomorrah?
properties.description:
An archeological site 2.5 km NW of Tel el Hammam.
Excavations at site found similar finds like in Tel el-Hamam, i.e. destruction at the end of MB, and resettlement in the Iron age.
Collins suggests locating here Biblical Gomorrah, and the early Iron age "Beit Yesimot"
Bibliography:
Τhanasis J. Papadopoulos, “The Hellenic Archaeology Project of the University of Ioannina in Jordan: A Preliminary Synthesis of the Excavation Results at Ghawr as-Sāfī and Tall Al-Kafrayn (2000-2004),” in Studies in the History and Archaeology of Jordan, ed. Fawwaz al-Khraysheh, IX (Amman: Department of Antiquities, 2007), 189.

properties.name: Tell Deir Alla / Sukkoth?
properties.description:
A Biblical Period mound 40 NE of Jericho, Identified by many scholars with Biblical "Sukkoth". If indeed so, here is where Jacob set up tabernacles, an event that gave the site its name (Gen. 33:17).
Gideon confronted the "Elders of Sukkoth" (Jud. 8), and Solomon quarried copper Between "Succoth and Zeredata" (I Kings 7:46).
The site was excavated by Leiden U and Jordan Ant. dprt. during the years 1960-1984. The excavated areas can be seen clearly from this aerial view.
An important inscription recovered at the site relates to the prophet Balaam (cf. Num. 22-24).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tell Mazar
properties.description:
Located in the central East Jordan valley, Tell el-Mazar was excavated between 1977 to 1981 by Dr. Khair Yassine from Jordan University.the excavationss revealed an almost continuous occupation from the Late Bronze Age to the Persian period.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tell es-Sa'idiyeh / Zeredath?/ Tsafon?
properties.description:
Biblical period mound on the eastern side of the Jordan river, about half way between the Dead Sea and the Sea of Galilee.The site was excavated by an expedition from the University of Pennsylvania Museum in 1964-1965, and by a team from the British Museum between 1985 to 1996.The excavations revealed occupational evidence from the Early Bronze Age, and Late Bronze Age to Early Islamic periods.The Lower Tell was used extensively as a cemetery, yielding one of the largest excavated burial samples (over 500 burials) in the Northern region of Israel-Palestine and Transjordan.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Pella / Tabaqat Pahl
properties.description:
Tabaqat Pahl
A site on the eastern banks of the Jordan River, inhabited continiously since the Neolithic period (c. 10,000 BCE).
It was named "Pella" in the Hellenistic period, probably in honor of the birhtplace of Alexander the Great.
In the Roman period it was member of the Decapolis, a league of ten cities.
In the first century the Judeo-Christians fled to Pella from Jerusalem, because of the Great Jewish Revolt (66-70 CE).
For some of the excavations at the site, click here (http://www.astarte.com.au/html/pella_s_canaanite_temple.html)

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Dion / Bayt Ras
properties.description:
Dion was a member of the Decapolis, a league of ten cities from the Roman period in Trans-Jordan. The location of the city is uncertain, but perhaps it is at Bay Ras, north of Irbid.
As you can see, left of the placemark a Roman period theatre was discovered.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Abila / Raphana / Tel Abil
properties.description:
A ancinet city, inhabited in Canaanite to Byzantine periods.
According to some source, by the name Raphana, Abila was a member of the Decapolis, a league of ten cities during the Roman Period.
For up to date information about the excavations at the site, go to: www.abila.org (http://www.abila.org)

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Gadara / Umm Qais
properties.description:
A Roman period city, which was a member of the decapolis - a league of ten cities, mentioned also in the New Testament. Excavations at the site revealed various structure, walls, tombs, and two theatres, that can be seen clearly on both sides of the placemark. Sould include a local museum at "Al-Roussan" house.

For more information about the Site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Umm el Jimmal
properties.description:
A well preserved Byzantine period site in Eastern Jordan.
Being built only of stone, some of the houses have their windows preserved, as well as cielings and staircases. The building technique documented here is called "Haurinte architecture".

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Gerasa / Jerash
properties.description:
Roman period city, memebr of the Decapolis, which is well preserved to this day. In fact this Sattelite view provides an exellent image of the the main street (Cardo), with two piazzas. On both side of the city the theatres are clearly visible, as well as the Hyppodrome near the southern entrance.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.description:
Member of the Decapolis, a league of ten cities from the Roman Period.
Excavations at the site revealed various structure, but I need better resolution to hopefully locate places like the theatre, nympheaum, and Christian Basilica.

properties.name: "Bethany Beyond the Jordan" - Ancient Baptising Pool?
properties.description:
A Large plastered pool along Wadi Kharrar is believed to be, according to the its excavator, M. Waheeb, an ancient immersion facility used by pilgrims for baptising. 

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: "Bethany Beyond the Jordan" - Modern Baptising Pools
properties.description:
Aside the large scale excavations along Wadi Kharrar, which is identified with "Bethany Beyond the Jordan", the minstry of Tourism of Jordan also created a complex of modern and comfortable facilities for pilgrims to baptise in the water of springs in this area, presumably the same waters used by John the Baptist in the first century.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Ain Feshkha
properties.description:
A large structure in the vicinity of a set of weet water springs.
Excavations at the site dated it to the Roman period, and documented a set of pools. Being close to Qumran some scholars argued that the Scrolls (found near Qumran) were perhaps prepered here, in the pools which were full of urine..

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/qumran

properties.name: Qumran
properties.description:
Roman period site, built as a fortress, but contains many additional unique fetures, such as purifing facilities, a large dinning room, and a cemetery where 1100 (!) tombs were counted (on the hille east of the site).
Yet it is most famous for the scrolls found in the caves around the sites, known as the "Dead Sea Scrolls".The scrolls document a Jewish sect which dwelt in Qumran and anticipated the end of days. Some scholars argue John the Baptist may have been a member of this community for a while.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/qumran

properties.name: Qumran Cave #1
properties.description:
The very first cave discovered, which contained 7 of the famous Dead Sea Scrolls.
In total the Dead Sea Scrolls make a library of over 900 manuscripts, which was hidden in the caves near Qumran around 66 CE.
The scrolls contain copies of the Old Testament, Commentaries, and rules of behavior for members of a Jewish sect that called itself "Yahad".
Most of the scrolls are exhibited today at the Israel Museum.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/qumran

properties.name: Qumran Cave #3
properties.description:
One of the caves where the famous Dead Sea Scrolls were found.
In total the Dead Sea Scrolls make a library of over 900 manuscripts, which was hidden in the caves near Qumran around 66 CE.
The scrolls contain copies of the Old Testament, Commentaries, and rules of behavior for members of a Jewish sect that called itself "Yahad".
Most of the scrolls are exhibited today at the Israel Museum. One famous scroll found here, the Copper Scroll, is ehibited in the Jordan Archaeological Museum,

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/qumran

properties.name: Qumran caves #4-5
properties.description:
Some of the caves where the famous Dead Sea Scrolls were found.
In total the Dead Sea Scrolls make a library of over 900 manuscripts, which was hidden in the caves near Qumran around 66 CE.
The scrolls contain copies of the Old Testament, Commentaries, and rules of behavior for members of a Jewish sect that called itself "Yahad".
