properties.name: Qasr el-Yahud \ el Ma'atas - Baptism Site
properties.description:
A site on the western bank of the Jordan river venerated by Christians as the very site where John the Baptist baptised Jesus. The site was inaccessible for many years, but since the peace accord between Israel and Jordan in 1994 the site is open again for pilgrims. Every year, on 18-19 of January, the "Epiphany" ceremonies conducted at the site by the Eastern churches, with many participants.On the eastern side of the Jordan the Jordanians have excavated and developed the site for pilgrims and tourism as well.The sattelite view shows mostly the empty parking lot, but if it was taken on 18 of January 2006, it would have showed many many buses, as about 15,000 pilgirms attented the ceremony!.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/qasr-el-yahud-baptism-site

properties.name: Qasr el-Yahud - Abandoned Churches
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/qasr-el-yahud-baptism-site

properties.name: Qasr El-Yahud - John the Baptist Monastery
properties.description:
Byzantine period monastery, now owned by the Greek-Orthodox Church. It's name, Qasr el-Yahud (=Fortress of the Jews) preserves the tradition that it is here where the Israelites crossed the Jordan River to settle in the Promised Land. Yet the site is more known in relation to the John the Baptist, who, according to the Christian tradition, baptised Jesus in the Jordan river just east of the monastery. Every year on the 18-19 of January the eastern church conduct a ceremony that begins with a parade from this monastery and ends with a mass baptising event at the Jordan river.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/qasr-el-yahud-baptism-site

properties.name: Deir Hajlah / Gerasimus' Monastery
properties.description:
Monastic complex inhabited continiously since Byzantine period.
It was founded by the monk Gerasimus, and according to the local tradition he was escorted and protected by a lion after removing a thorne from his paw.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/deir-hajla-gerasimus-monastery

properties.description:
Possible location of Biblical "Hogla"

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Laura of Gerasimus
properties.description:
A set of caves carved in cliffs above a small spring, possibly the location of the Byzantine "laura" monastery founded by the hermit Gerasimus in the 5th century CE

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/laura-of-gerasimus

properties.name: Ein Gedi - Chalcolithic Shrine
properties.description:
On a cliff with a beautiful view towrads the Dead Sea Y. Aharoni excavated in the 1950's a unique Fifth millenia BCE shrine. WIth no contemporary settlement the origin of the users of the shrine is a mystery.
In the 1960's P. Bar-Adon found in a cave 11 km south from here a Chalcolithic bronze hoard, that perhaps originated from this shrine.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Ancient Ein-Gedi
properties.description:
Greko-Roman site, inhabited most of the time by Jews. in the 70's a synagogue was found in the center of the village, including an inscription mentioning "the secret of the village".The Secret is perhaps the manufcatoring process of the balsam perfume, which was very costly.Recent excavations around the synagogue by Y. Hirschfeld may have found traces of that industry.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ein-gedi-synagogue

properties.name: Sink Holes
properties.description:
A new and dengarous phenomena that is spreading on the banks of the Dead Sea in the last few years.
Sudden holes, in the size from 1m to 20m are suddenly created, in most cases in estuaries of wadis. Some of them are later with with water.
Geologist suggest this is caused because of the drying of the Dead Sea.
Interestingly enough, this phenomena is already recorded in the Bible:"Now the Valley of Siddim was full of tar pits, and when the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled, some of the men fell into them and the rest fled to the hills.(Genesis 14:10).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Cave of the Horror
properties.description:
In the 1960's famed archaeologist Y. Yadin found in a cave just below the placemark evidence of Jewish rebels who perrished in the Bar-Kokhva rebellion (132-135 CE). The reason for the death of the rebels can be seen right of the placemark - a small Roman army camp, to insure the rebels die of thirst and starvation.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: The Cave of the Letters
properties.description:
In the 1960's famed archaeologist Y. Yadin found in a cave just below the placemark evidence of Jewish rebels who perrished in the Bar-Kokhva rebellion (132-135 CE).
Perhaps the most amazing find was a set of lettres written by Bar-Kokhva himself to the rebels.
And if you keep in mind Yadin was chief of staff of IDF before his archaeological career, the find was an amazing event in which a chief of staff of the modern Jewish army read a letter made by the chief of staff of the last Jewish army in antiquity!!!.
The reason for the death of the rebels can be seen right of the placemark - a small Roman army camp, to insure the rebels die of thirst and starvation.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Nahal Mishmar - Cave of the Hoard
properties.description:
In this cave, in a steep cliff of Nahal Mishmar, and archaeological expedition led by P. Bar-Adon found a hoard of Fifth century BCE bronze artifacts.
The volunteers participating in the excavation thought this could be the treasures of the Jewish temple from Jersualem, but it really date to a much older, prehisotric period.
Theory is they were brought here from a Chalcolithic period shrine in Ein-Gedi, 11 km to the north.
The hoard is exhibited today in the Israel Museum, in Jerusalem.Some of the items retrieved in "The cave of the Hoard" in Nahal Mishmar.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Ein-Gedi  - The "Essene Site"
properties.description:
A site above the oasis of Ein-Gedi bearing two pools next to a small spring. Y. Hirschfeld was of the opinion this was the dwelling site of the Essenes. I personally led the excavations at the site and I totally dissagree. It was nothing more then a pool for irrigating the Balsam fields nearby in ancient times.

properties.name: Maresha - The Industrial Columbaria cave
properties.description:
A double cruciform shaped cave in maresha with more the 4000 niches for growing pigeons - the largest columbaria ever found in Israel.The pigeond were raised for their meat, manuer, and to be used as sacrifice, as was the demands both by comtemporary Jews, Samaritans, and the people of Ascalon.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Maresha - The Polish Cave
properties.description:
A bell shaped columbaria cave in Maresha named after graffitis left by Polish soldiers who chiseled on the center pole of the cae "WARSLAW" and "POLISH".

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Maresha - the Olive Press Cave
properties.description:
A bell shaped set of caves in Maresha used for producing olive oil in antiquity. Parts of the machines were restored by the national parks authority.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Maresha - The "Villa" Complex
properties.description:
A maze of underground cellars, halls, and rooms near the acropolis of Maresha, part of a Hellenistic era mansion.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Marissa-Maresha
properties.description:
Biblical site in the Shephela. Mentioned only once in the Bible, and indeed the finds are mostly from the Hellenistic period. The city was unique in being mostly underground, and a visit to a site includes mostly walking through a maze of caves.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Maresha - Complex 61
properties.description:
A maze of halls, cellars, and rooms from the Hellenistic period deiscovered near the acropolis of Maresha.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Maresha - The Sidonian Burial Cave
properties.description:
A kokhim cave in Maresha discovered in 1905, containing rich wall paintings and inscriptions, testifying it's original use by a mixed community of Sidonians and Edomites during the Hellenistic period.The wall paintings were vadalised by the locals after their discovery, yet recently the Israeli Nature Parks Authority had placed replicas of them.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Maresha - Sandanna church
properties.description:
An Apsis is all that remains of a large church that was constructed at this site by the Crusaders. The church was dedicated to Saint Anne, Mother of Mary.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Maresha - The "Bell Caves" Complex
properties.description:
A set of bell shaped caves complex on the northern part of Maresha National park. Originally it was formed by large scale quarrying activity. Today it is known as a unique place for concerts and weddings. One of the caves is also famous for fertilty capabilities, and some couples who fail to bear children the conventional way (in their own bed) try their luck in this cave. Some even succeed..

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/maresha

properties.name: Eleuthropolis-Beth Guvrin
properties.description:
A Roman period site in the Shephela. Its name ("city of the free man") may indicate it was founded by Roman slaves who managed to pay for their liberty.Excavations at the site found a well-preserved ampitheatre (to the left of the post), which may indicate that at least some of the free slaves had to comprimise with a dangerous career as out of their free choice.During the crusaders period a large church was constructed at the site, jus to the right of the post.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/beit-guvrin

properties.name: Beit-Guvrin - The Roman Ampitheatre
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/beit-guvrin

properties.name: Tel Goded - Bar-Kokhva Hideout complex
properties.description:
A site 3 km NE of Beth-Guvrin where hideout complex from the time of Bar-Kokhva is available for crawling. Don't forget to bring your flashlights!!

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/bar-kokhba-caves

properties.name: Beit-Guvrin - The Crusaders Church
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/beit-guvrin

properties.name: Tel Lachish
properties.description:
Biblical site in the Shepela, scond in size and imprtance to Jerusalem. Excavations by Macalister in the 1930's revealed two canaanite shirnes, and important inscriptions.Excavations by D. Ussishkin in the 1970's revealed the dramatic evidence for the conquest of the site by Sennachrib in 701 BCE. A relief depicting his conquest of the site was found in his palace in Nineveh.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/lachish

properties.name: Tel Lachish - The Assyrian Ramp
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/lachish

properties.name: Tel Lachish - The Iron Age Gate Complex
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/lachish

properties.name: Tel Lachish - The Well
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/lachish

properties.name: Tel Lachish - The Late Bronze Fosse Temple
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/lachish

properties.name: Tel Lachish - The Iron Age Palace
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/lachish

properties.name: Tel Lachish - The "Solar Temple"
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/lachish

properties.name: Tel Lachish - Starkey's dump site
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/lachish

properties.name: Ascalon - The Canaanite Gate
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ashkelon

properties.name: Ascalon - The Roman Basilica
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ashkelon

properties.name: Ascalon - "Maria Viridis" Church
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ashkelon

properties.name: Ascalon - A Byzantine Church
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ashkelon

properties.name: Ascalon - Afridar Center
properties.description:
Includes a display of two beautifully carved Roman era Sarcophagi.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ashkelon

properties.name: Ascalon - Makam Hussein son of Ali
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ashkelon

properties.name: Tel Ascalon / Ashkelon
properties.description:
Historical site inhabited since Canaanite times. Excavations by an American team in the early 20th century CE revealed public buildings from the Roman periods. Recent excavations by Stager revealed remains from Canaanite and Israelite periods, including a metal calf.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ashkelon

properties.name: Ascalon - Sheikh Awad Tomb Mark
properties.description:
For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/ashkelon

properties.name: Givat Yona
properties.description:
By Christian tradition the place where the walke vomitted Jonah. By Muslim tradition his burial site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Ashdod Philistine Museum
properties.description:
For more information about the site
https://dannythedigger.com/ashdod-philistine-museum/
info@dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Ashdod
properties.description:
A Biblical tel, known to be a phlistine city during the Isralite period.
Excavations at the site by M. Dothan in the 1960's revealed various artifacts related to the philistines.
Recent salvage excavations near the tell revealed part of an Assyrian palace.

For more information about the site:    
https://dannythedigger.com/tel-ashdod/
info@dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Deir el-Balah
properties.description:
A Biblical period site south of Gazah.
Excavations by a team from the Hebrew University discovered here an Egyptian style manor house (right above the placemark), and a cemetary of anthopoid coffins (right below the placemark).
Althougth the anthopoid coffins are typical to the Egyptians, they bear decorative elements typical to the Philishtines, and so it is there presumed that these were tombs of Philistines serving the Egyptians, and assimilating with their culture.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. Beer-Shema
properties.description:
A site in the Negev where a Byzantine period church was revealed, with a well preserved mosaic floor.
Inscriptions found at the site attest to the converstion of local nomads to Christianity, and that the church was dedicated to St. Stephan, the first Martyr in Christianity.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Haror / Gerar?
properties.description:
A ancient site 24 km NW of Beer-Sheba. It is possible here was Biblical Gerar, a city in the Negev where both Abraham and Isaac denied their wives (Genesis 21, 26).
The site hasn't been excavated yet.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Sera' / Ziklag?
properties.description:
A site in the Negev 20 km NW of Beer-Sheva.
Large-scale excavations from 1972 to 1978 by Ben-Gurion University expedition under the direction of E.D. Oren uncovered the rich settlement assemblages from the Chalcolithic through the Byzantine periods.
The excavated area can be seen right below the placemark.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Abraham's well
properties.description:
An ancient well in the center of the Modern city of Beer-Sheba, named after Abraham.
Excavations in various locations in modern Beer-Sheba revealed sites inhabited in the fourth millenium BCE (the prehistoric "Chalcolithic" Period).], 2000 years before the days of Abraham.
The "Chalcolithic" period people were known for their bronze and ivory art.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/abrahams-well

properties.name: Tel Beer-Sheba
properties.description:
Biblical site in Southern Israel. Excavated in the 70's of the 20th century by Y. Aharoni, the site yielded a well planned city from the Israelite period, and rich in finds, most important was a stone altar.
Recent excavation have exposed the water system of the site, and recently it was opend to the public.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tel-beer-sheva

properties.name: Tel Arad - the Israelite fortress
properties.description:
The acropolis of Tel Arad was fortified during the Israelite period (c. 1000-586 BCE). It was exacvated by Y. Aharoni in the 1970's. The most Amazing find was a local Judahic shrine, sanctifing two masseboth. In another part of the fortress important ostraca were found, containing orders to the commander of the fort, and warning him from the Edomites from the south. The post is exacatly over the water reservoir which is still waiting to be reveaeld.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tel-arad

properties.name: Tel Halif / Ziklag?
properties.description:
A Biblical site 17 km N of Beer-Sheba.
Continious excavations at the site since 1976 revealed occupation layers from the Canaanite, Israelite and Persian periods.
Some scholars argue the site is Biblical Ziklag, a Philistine city where David and some of his men and wives spent more then a year (I Sam. 27:6, 29).
Other scholars sugget Ziklag should be located at Tel-'Sera, and this site should be idntified as Biblical Rimmon. See discussionhere.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com (http://www.tfba.org/articles.php?articleid=9)

properties.name: Kh. Sussiah
properties.description:
An ancient Jewish village from the Roman-Byzantine Period.
It was excavated thouroughly by A. Negev in the 1970's, yet to this day the name of the site in antiquity remains unknown.
To the left of the placemark you can clearly see the red roof over the ancient synagogue that was discovered at the site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Ma'on
properties.description:
Biblical site in the southern Hebron mountains known as the hometown of Nabal (I Sam. 25:2).
Nabal had many goats and sheep which David desired.
When Naal heard that he apperently had a heart attack and died.
David then married his wife, Abigail.
Excavatios at the site revealed a Byzanitine period synagogue, including a rare fragment of a marble Menorah.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. es-deir / Aenon?
properties.description:
An ancient site 6 km W of Hebron. It's Arabic name, kh. es-deir, means - "ruins of the monastery". Survey of the site done by Kopp and steve in the 1960's revealed a monastic complex from the Byzantine period, including a church with a large baptistry in its apse. The baptisterium was fed by an aquaduct bringing water from nearby spring whose Arabic name "Ain el-Ma'amudieh" means "Spring of the Baptising".
A Baptising site west of Hebron is mentioned by Crusaders period sources, and these sources identify the site with "Aenon" mentioned in John 3:23.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Zif / Aristobolia
properties.description:
For more information about the Site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Cave of the Patriachs
properties.description:
According to Jewish, Muslim, and Christian tradition, the burial place of the Biblical Patriarchs and Matriarchs.A well built structure was built over the tombs in the Roman period, perhaps by King Herod. Survey of the cave done By N. Dayan after the six days war (1967) revealed that indeed there is a double cave underground.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/cave-of-the-patriarchs

properties.name: Mamre oaks? / Ramat el Khalil
properties.description:
Mysterious site in northern Hebron, where remains a of a large structure from the Roman period are visible (The rectangular shape is very clear even from space!..)Some suggest the building was erected by Herod to emphasize his Jewish roots, as it is over "Mamre Oaks", where Abraham built an alter (Genesis 14:13).
Others syuggest this is an Edomite shrine.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. Beit Einun / Aenon?
properties.description:
A Biblical site in north of Hebron, Perhaps Beith-Anot (Joshua 15:59). Excavations at the site by Y. Magen revealed a Byzantine period church. Some scholars argue the site could be "Aenon" mentioned in John 3:23, where John the Baptist was active. in Near by site Kh. Abu Reish large pools were found, perhaps in relation to baptism activity.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. Abu Reish
properties.description:
A church complex from the Byzantine period north of Hebron. Excavations at the site by Y. Baruch and Y. Magen revealed water pools near the church, and an inscription mentioning "the pilgrims to this holy site".
Y. Baruch suggests to identify this site as "Aenon which is near Salim" (John 3:23), a site where John the Baptist was active.
To the west, a site by the name "Kh. Beit Einun" may have preserved the ancient name "Aenon"; and "Salim" should be identified at no other then Jerusalem, which in the day of Abraham may have been known by the name "Shalem" (Genesis 14:18).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Erani
properties.description:
Canaanite site once believed to be Biblical Gath. However excavations at the site showed the site was abanodoned at the end of the Early Bronze period, a thousand years before the Philistines New they existed.
Nevertheless the modern city built near the tell preserves the mistake in research and is named "Kiryat Gath" (The city of Gath).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel es-Safi / Gath?
properties.description:
Biblical site in the Shephela. Ongoing excavations by A. Maier no behalf of Bar-Ilan university have found a unique siege wall around the site, perhaps the one made By Hazael king of Aram (II Kings 12:18), an ostraca with perhaps the name "Goliath" written on it, and phallic shaped clay objects, perhaps item of worship of the Philistines.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Luzit Caves - Bar-kokhva hideout complex
properties.description:
A site near the main caves complex, where a hideout complex from the time of the Bar-Kokhva rebellion is available for crawling thru. Don't forget to bring your flashlights!!.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Luzit Caves
properties.description:
A set of man made bel shaped caves in the Shephela, formed during the Byzantine and Early Muslim Periods, as a result of large scale quarrying activity.Today the site is known for week-end tourism, rappeling, and full moon parties..

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/luzit-caves

properties.name: Collection of Roman Milestones
properties.description:
A site on the side of the modern road, which is following a Roman period road between Gaza / Eleuthropolis and Jerusalem. The mile stones attest to the maintanance of the road by the Roman authorities in the third century. Look NE for the site where carved steps of that road were recovered (near Kh. Khanoth.)
This road is also mentioned in the Book of Acts (8:26).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Azekah
properties.description:
Biblical site in teh Shephela. Was the army post of the Israelites during the battle between David and Goliath. The site is also mentioned in the famous Lachish letters.On the eastern slopes of the site the Bar-Kokhva rebels dug a set of caves. Visiting them requires torches, and a string..

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/azekah

properties.name: David vs. Goliath Battle site?
properties.description:
The presumed site of the famous battle between David and Goliath, because:A. it is located between Azekah and Socho.B. There are pebbles in the dry river bed, of the type David may have used.Look to the left (west) for Tel Azekah, and to the right (east) for Socho.follow the map NEE to locat Kh. Khanoth, the traditional burial place of Goliath.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Kh. Ethri
properties.description:
A Roman period Jewish village in the shephela revealed in recent years by B. Zissu from Bar Ilan Univeristy.A popular account of the excavations has been published in BAR 33/5 (2007).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Socho
properties.description:
Biblical site in the Shephala famous as the site where the Philistines camped before the bettle between David and Golaith. Look west for the battle site at Efes Damim, and NE for the traditional burial site of Goliath at Kh. Khanoth.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Adullam Cave
properties.description:
Adullam is first mentioned in the bible in Genesis 38:1-2 as where Judah "knew" a Canaaninte women called "Shua".
According to Joshua 12:15 King of Adulam was one of the 31 kings defeated by Joshua, and so later it becomes in the lot of the tribe of Judah (15:35).
I Sam. 22 records David hiding from Saul in Adulam, recruiting "bitter people", and later fighting the Philistines from this base (1 Sam. 23:13).
II Chronicles 11:7 indicates Adulam was among the site fortified by Rechoboam. Micha Prophesizes its destruction (1:16). It is resettled by the Jews returning from Babylon (Nehemiah 11:30), and was where Judas purified after a significant victory in Maresha (2 Mac. 12:3).
The site is identified at Khirbet Sheich el Madkur. The site beneath ([Eid] El Maya) is preserving the sound of the ancient name. It has not been excavated yet.
For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Beit Nattif
properties.description:
A site in the shephela where excavations in the 1930's revealed an important oil lamp work shop from the late Roman period. The type of oil lamps produced at the site are known in the literature as "Beit Nattif Oil Lamps".

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Yarmuth
properties.description:
A Biblical site in the Shephela. Excavations at the site by P. Miroschedji revealed remains from the Early Bronze period which indicate the Egyptian had an administrative center at the site.Below the placemark you can see the excavated area. The acropolis (above the placemark) is still waiting to be excavated.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Roman Period Carved Ascent
properties.description:
On the side of the modern road leading to Jersualem, at this spot, a set of ancient carved steps can be seen.
This road in mentioned in the Book of Acts:"Now an angel of the Lord said to Philip, "Go south to the road—the desert road—that goes down from Jerusalem to Gaza." (Acts 8:26).
However the carving of these steps was probably done later, in the 3rd century CE.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Beth Jimmal
properties.description:
A monastery preserving a Christian tradition that here the tomb of Gamliel the Jewish sage was found.Recent excavations around the site revealed remains of monasteries from the Byzantine period.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/beit-jimal

properties.name: Tel Beth-Shemesh
properties.description:
Biblical site in the Shephela. The name of the site is preserved by the spring neat by, Ain Shamsh. The biblical name may indicate a canaanite center for the worship of the sun, but most of the finds are the Israelite period. Recent excavations by S. Bonimovits and Z. Lederman revealed a hidden water reservoir, and an important work-shop for iron tools.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/beth-shemesh

properties.name: Kh. Khanot - Goliaths' tomb?
properties.description:
A caravaserai on the way from the Sehephela to Jerusalem was identified in the Byzantine perioed as the burial site of Goliath (excluding his head..). A rujum marks his tomb, and a chapell near by probably provided religious services to the pilgrims.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Batash / Timnah
properties.description:
A site in the Shephela identified as Biblical Timnah, where Judah had sheep (Genesis 38:12).
The site was excavated by A. Mazar in the 1990's.
The site is also mentioned in 6th century CE madaba map as"Thamna, where Judah Sheared his Sheap" (http://www.christusrex.org/www1/ofm/mad/legends/legends067.html), but some scholars are of the opionion that during the Byzantine period Timnah was idetified at kh. Mannah, a site in the vicinity of Modi'in, 20 km NE from Tel Batash.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel-Mikne - Ekron
properties.description:
Biblical site, known as one of the cities of the Philishtines. Exacavations at the site by S. Gitin and T. Dothan revealed shrines, walls, and olive presses, but their most important find is a dedicatory inscription made by 'Achish, governor of Ekron". The inscription finally proves the identification of the site with Biblical Ekron.
Much of the site is covered by wild plants today, but in the near by kibbutz of Revadim is a nice museum.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Emmaus-Nicopolis
properties.description:
A Roman period city which developed into a christian holy place, preserving the tradition as the site where Jesus appeared to a few people after his resurrection (Luke 24:13-35).Excavations at the site revealed a crusaders cathedral, and Roman period mosaic floors. Much of the Roman city is still waiting to be exposed.Being too far from Jerusalem according to the NT acount, other sites have been identified as the Emmaus mentioned in Luke, closer to Jerusalem (Abu-Gosh, Kubeibah, and Motsa).

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/emmaus-nicopolis

properties.name: Tel Ayalon / Ajalon
properties.description:
Biblical site where according to the book of Joshua (10:12) The moon "stood still" , thus aiding Joshua to triumph over the Canaanites. The site was built by the crusaders as a fortress.
The site is still waiting to be excavated.Above the placemark, near the visible parking lot, is a Roman period structure over the local spring.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Shaar Hagai Milestones
properties.description:
A cluster of milestone  along the ancient road from Jeruslem to Emmaus, Lod, and Jaffa. Only one of them is readable, and dates to the days emperor Maximianus (235-238 CE). Unfortunately the destination and distance are missing. 

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Gezer
properties.description:
Major Biblical site in the Shephela. According to the Bible it was given by Pharaoh to Solomon (I Kings 9:15-16). Was excavated by Macalister and later by Dever. The excavations revealed two well preserved gates (Canaanite and Israelite), a water system, and an impressive Canaanite stelae complex.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tel-gezer

properties.name: kh. Beit-Anabah
properties.description:
An ancient site on the side of Jerusalem - Tel-Aviv moden highway, identified as Biblical Anob (Jos. 11:21). The site is also mentioned in Madaba Map, asAnob, now Betoannaba (http://www.christusrex.org/www1/ofm/mad/legends/legends068.html).

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Umm el-Umdan / Modi'in?
properties.description:
A site revealed by the Israel Antiquities Authority during slavage excavations in this region. Sh. Weksler-Bdolah and A. Onn revealed here a a unique complex of a synagogue and a mikveh from the 2nd century BCE, the time of the Hasmoneans, and so it was suggested here is ancient Modi'in. The Arabic name of the site may have also preserved the original name of the village.
On the other side of the modern road a set of contemporary tombs were also revealed. Read more about these tombs here (http://www.hadashot-esi.org.il/report_detail_eng.asp?id=321&mag_id=111).

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/modiin

properties.name: Titurah hill/ Modi'in?
properties.description:
A large ancient site on the main road from the coastal plain to Jerusalem. Archaeologist Sh. Gibson, who excavated at the site, suggests here lies ancient Modi'in.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/modiin

properties.name: Kh. Kefar Ruth
properties.description:
An ancient site in the vicinity of ancient and modern Modi'in.
Although never excavated, it is identified correctly as "KAFERUTHA" (http://www.christusrex.org/www1/ofm/mad/legends/legends063.html) mentioned in Madaba map, a mosaic map from the sixth century.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: kh. Manna
properties.description:
A site in the vicinity of Modi'in which is perhaps "Thamnah" mentioned in Madaba map. If so, then the identification of the site "moved" during the Byzantine period from the actuall site, which is identified at Tel Batash, 20 km SE of kh. mannah.
Excavation at the site revealed a Byzantine period apsidial church.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Beth Horon Ascent
properties.description:
Famous ascent on the road from the coastal plain to Jerusalem. Joshua chased Canaanite kings on this road, and was aided by heil stones (Joshua 10:11). The Maccabees ambushed the Seleucids going up the ascent (I Hasmoneans 15). To this day a main road, which connects Modi'in area with Jerusalem climbs this ascent.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Lod - St. George Church
properties.description:
A church in the center of Lod dedicated to St. George / Georgius. Georgius, who was born in Lod, was a Christian believer and a Roman army officer. When Diocletian gave orders to hunt Christians, he tore the order, thus revealing his true identity.
He was put to death.
Being a symbol of a Christian and an army man, Richard Lionheart made him patron of England, and that's why George is a very common English name to this day.
British mediaval mythology also argues he killed a dragon.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Lod / Diospolis
properties.description:
Lod is an urban site inhaabited continiously since the Roman period.
In the Roman period it was known by the name DIOSPOLIS - "The city of Zeus".
In the Byzantine period it was also known by the name GEORGIOPOLIS - "the city of Georgius", in honor of a native of the city who became a famous Christian martyr (See below at the placemark of the church named after him!).
During those days Lod was also known as a Jewish cultural and religious center.
The placemark is over an area where in the 1990's by chance a big and beautiful mosaic floor was found. However lacking budget for conservation, to this day the mosaic floor is covered with protective sand, and is not visible.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Hadid
properties.description:
A site near the city of Lod, identified with Biblical Adithaim (Jos. 15:36).
The site is also mentioned in the sixth century CE Madaba map, as "Adithaim now Aditha" (http://www.christusrex.org/www1/ofm/mad/legends/legends065.html). 
The plural ending of "Adithaim" suggest there may have been two sites by that name.
In 1995-1996 an unamed site 2 km to the north was uncovered in salvage excavations of the IAA. It is possible that the other unamed site was also called "Hadid", at least in the days of the Hasmoneans.

For more details about the site:
http://www.antiquities.org.il/site_Item_heb.asp?id=117
Dahari U. 1999, ‘Adithaim now Aditha and Betomelgezis in the Madaba Map’, in: The Madaba Map Centenary (1897-1997) Travelling Through the Byzantine Umayyad Period, eds. Michele Piccirillo and Eugenio Alliata, Stadium Biblicum Franciscanum, Collectio Maior 40, pp. 246-248.

properties.name: Kh. Tinshemet
properties.description:
A site excavated by the IAA in the 1990's when High way #6 was constucted nearby. The iste yielded a Byzantine monastic complex rich in finds.
Near it the IAA revealed a large site whose remains included a large fortress from the Hasmonean period.
U. Dahari, excavator of that site, suggests this is the site of "Hadid", which was fortified by Simon the Maccabean (Has. I 12:38). Since there is already another site by that name, Dahari suggests there were actually two sites by the same name. Indeed in Jos. 15:36, Madaba map, and the Onomasticon of Eusebius the site is labels in plural - "Adithaim", and not "hadid"!

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: New False site of the tombs of the Hasmoneans
properties.description:
A site excavated in 1996 by Sh. Riklin of the IAA, and identifing some names mentioned on some the ossuaries with Hasmonean figures, he suggested these are the tombs of the Royal Hasmonean family.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: False site of the tombs of the Hasmoneans
properties.description:
Site falsly known as the tomb of the Hasmoneans, perhaps because of the Arabic name of the site - "Qubur el Yahud" (=Tombs of the Jews). The real site is perhaps a bit north, next to "Sheikh el-Gharbawi", but it is still waiting to be revealed properly.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tomb of the Hasmoneans?
properties.description:
This site, known in Arabic as "Seikh el Ghrabawi" and in Hebrew as "Kh. Hagardi" is just west of El-Midiyeh (Modi'in), and excavations at the site by V. Gueren revealed perhaps remains of the royal sepulchre of the Hasmoneans. Furthermore, if you tilt the map to the west, you can see the sea, and the book of Hasmoneans states that the tomb was seen even from the sea!.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: El-Midiyeh / Modi'in
properties.description:
Arab village in the Shephela whose name may indicate it is at the site of ancient Modi'in, hometown of the Maccabees. The book of the Hasmoneans records a royal family tomb which may have been on the hill east of the site.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Mazor Mausuleum
properties.description:
A late Roman period Mausoleum on the side of the ancient international road between Egypt and Mesopotamia (VIA MARIS).The building is preserved to its cieling to this day because a Muslim tradition identified the site as the burial place of "Nebi Yichya" - "(The) prohpet John (the Baptist)".

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/mausoleum-mazor

properties.name: Mirabel / Migdal Zedek
properties.description:
A Crusaders period fortress, reinhabited in the 19th century by an Arab from Sechem named "Sadek el Gumeini", who was known as a road robber..The site was then known by the name as "Magdel Sadek" (the tower of Sadek).
After 1948 The state of Israel decided to give the site a Hebrew name, and so based on the sound of its Arabic name, it was renamed "Migdal Tsedek" - The tower of Justice(!). A bit Ironic that a site of a famous bandit is now officialy called "The tower of Justice"....

The site is currently under a preservation project and so is closed to the public.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Aphek
properties.description:
Biblical Site built at the pass of the VIA MARIS ("Road of the Sea") near the sources of the Yarkon stream.
Excavations at the site b M.Kochavi reavealed remains of an Egyptian style governor Mansion, very rich in finds, including important cuneiform tablets.
In the beginning of the Ottoman period (1572-4) a fortress was built over the egyptian remains, to monitor the important road and water source. It was named "Pinar bashi" ("Head of the springs" in Turkish).
A common mistake is to identify the fortress with the Roman city Antipatris, and so some call it "The Antipatris fortress".

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/aphek-antipatris

properties.name: Antipatris
properties.description:
A Roman city founded by King Herod in 9 BCE over the remains of Biblical Aphek. The site was destoyed by the Romans in 68 CE, but later rebuilt. It suffered much from the earthquake in 363 CE, yet continued to be inhabited througout the Byzantine and Early Muslim periods.
The site is imotalized in Christian history as Paul spent there night when he was on the way to Caesarea (Acts 23:31).
Excavations at the site by M. Kokhavi revealed part of the city. The Post is right over the Odeon (small theatre) revaled at the site. Above the post you can clearly see the cardo (main street) of the site. Most of the city, however, still waits for its discovery.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/aphek-antipatris

properties.name: Izbet Sarta / Eben Ha'ezer?
properties.description:
A site on the side of the modern city of Rosh-Ha-Ayin, identified by some scholars with Biblical "Even Ha-ezer", the site from where the Israelites went to confront the Philishtines camping in Aphek.
In that battle the Israelites lost, and their rk of the covenant went to captivity.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Qasile
properties.description:
Biblical tel on the northern bank of the Yarkon river. Excavations at the site by A. Mazar in the 1970's revealed artifacts related to the Philistines.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Jaffa - "Tabitha kumi" church
properties.description:
A Holy Christian site east of Jaffa comomorating the miracouls ressuction of a young girl named Tabhita by Peter, which took place in Jaffa (Acts 9).
The reason for sanctifing the event at this spot is the find of a set of Roman period Jewish tombs in this plot during the 19th century, and one of the stone coffins found was believed to be marked with the name "Tabhita".
Left of the placemaek you can clearly see the top of the red tower of the church.
The site is usually closed for visits.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/saint-peter-and-saint-tabitha-russian-orthodox-church

properties.name: Jaffa - Roof of the house of Simon the Tanner by Armenian Tradition
properties.description:
Although thru Google Earth you see mostly roofs, how many of them are actually mentioned in the Bible?? - this one is!.
According to Christian tradition the roof of the house left of the placemark is the very roof on which Paul had a vision in which an angel told him he could eat also non-kosher food (acts 10).The site, known as "Simon the tanner's house" is private property and always closed, so you are actually getting a better view at the site from here then you would by visiting the place!.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/jaffa

properties.name: Jaffa - Andromeda Rock
properties.description:
Set of rocks near the harbor of Jaffa where according to the Greek mythology Andromeda was chained, to be given as sacrifice to the sea monster so the city will be delivered. Fortunately for her Perseus passed by and rescued her, but if you watch the rocks from the shore and listen carefully, you can still here the chains..

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/jaffa

properties.name: Jaffa / Ioppa
properties.description:
Biblical site inhabited continously since Canaanite times.
According to Greek Mythology the local princess was almost sacrificed to the sea monster, but rescued by Perseus (look for my place mark "Andromeda rock" at the entrance to Jaffa port!).
The New Testament records that in Jaffa Peter resurrected a girl (look for placemark "Tavitah kumi" east o Jaffa), and had a vision where he was directed to eat non kosher food, thus freeing Christianity from keeping kosher (look 100 m SW!)

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/jaffa

properties.name: Yavneh - R Shimon Ben Gamliel Tomb?
properties.description:
A site west of the tell of Yavneh is venerated by Jews as the tomb of one of the most important Jewish sages who lived in Yavne in the 2nd century CE - R. Shimon son of Gamliel.
It is very doubtfull if indeed the Rabbi is buried there. The structure was built in the Mamluk period (13th century), in honor of Hureirah, one of the friend of Mohamad.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Yavneh
properties.description:
Yavneh has a long and reach history. The book Joshua mentions it as a border site with the Philistines (Jos. 15:11), and Chronicles records how Uziyahu captured it from the Philistines (II Chr. 26:6).
The site is mentioned also in Hellenistic reocrds, but it is most famous from the Late Roman period, when following the destruction of the Jewish temple in Jerusalem, the Highest Jewish council (the "Sanhedrin") settled in Yavneh, and here the Mishna was arranged.
Later the site was inhabited by Samaritans, Christians, and Muslims. The crusaders added a fortress on the south side of the tell, visible to this day.
Salvage excavations north of the tell in 2002 discovered an important hoard of Philistine cultic vessels. They were restored an displayed in Eretz-Israel Museum during 2006.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Tel Arad
properties.description:
Biblical site east of Beer sheva, known from the Bible as a site of battle between the Israelites and Canaanites (Numbers 21). Although the text suggests the Israelites won, they later had to continue "around the Red Sea", and so it appears there was no Israelite victory at this site..Worse, archaeological research at the lower city (exactly where thre placemark is) revealed a city from the third millenia BCE, that means there were no Canaanites at the site when supposdly the Israelites were going out of Egypt (!!). The finds here, and at Ai (look for the post!..) are important for the study of Bible historiography.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/tel-arad

properties.name: Carmel
properties.description:
Biblical site in the southern Hebron mountains where according to the Bible a man called Nabal had many goats and sheep, and a wife "of a beautiful countenance" named Abigail (I Sam. 25:3).
David desired some of his flock, and ended up marrying his wife, after he passed away because of apperently a heart attack.
The site is inhabited to this day, and called in Arabic KIRMIL.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Carmel Prehistoric caves site
properties.description:
An important Prehistoric site in Norhtern Israel, where in a series of caves evidence of human activity from several prehistoric periods was recorded. Perhaps most important is the finding of Homo Sapiens and Neanderthals at the same site, suggesting they did interact, and perhaps mated.

For more information about the site:
info@dannythedigger.com
www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Muchraka
properties.description:
A mountain top Identified by Christian tradition as the site of the confrontation between Elijah and the prophets of Ba'al (I Kings 18).
The site is held by a Christian order named after the mountain - The Carmelites.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/muhraka

properties.name: Tel Yokneam
properties.description:

www.dannythedigger.com

properties.name: Ancient Beth-Shearim
properties.description:
Major Ancient Jewish site in lower Galilee. Following the destruction of the Jewish temple in Jerusalem in 70 CE, various Jewish sites in the Galilee developed as new Jewish Cultural centers. In the second century CE the Sanherdin (The Jewish “High court”) resided in Beth-She’arim for a while. Its leader, R. Judah “the prince”, known also as the compiler of the “Mishna”, was also buried at the site. Perhaps for this reason the cemetery of Beth-She’arim was developed during the late Roman period into a necropolis for Jews, both from the land of Israel, and from the Diaspora. The excavation of the site was the first major archaeological project by Jewish Archaeologists in Israel, taking place in the 1930’s and 1950’s.

For more information about the site:
http://dannythedigger.com/beth-shearim

properties.description:

https://dannythedigger.com/ashdod-yam/

properties.name: Ein Dirwa / Ethiopian Eunuch Baptism Site?
properties.description: A spring and remains of a byzantine era church next to it led some scholars to suggest this is the spring where Philip the Evangalist baptized the Ethiopian eunuch (Acts 8:26-40). This site seems to match its mention in the writings of Egaria, Paula, Theodosius, the the Pianceza pilgrim.  It also seems to fit the description in the Madaba map.  The other location proposed for this event is Ein Hania, 10 km SW of Jerusalem.  The other site fits better the desctiption of the even taking place along the road between Jerusalem and Gaza. However, it is possible that the road at the time passed through Hebron. The text itself admits the Jerusalem-Gaza road was out of use.

properties.name: Hill of the foreskins? Gilgal?
properties.description: According to Hagai ben-Arzi the site as unnatural large numbers of flintstones not common to this side of the Jordan river. In his opinion they were brought from the east bank of the river, and if so, he proposes that this is the site where Joshua verified all the Israelites were circumcised (5:2-9). If indeed so then this is also the site of Gilgal!!

properties.name: Tel Mar Elias
properties.description: "Listib" in the Byzantine period, identified with bilbical "Tishbe", hometown of prophet Eiljah. Visited by the pilgrim/ nun Egeria in 390 CE

properties.name: Qeilah
properties.description: I Samuel 23 records David saving the city from the Philistines, yet then Saul is after him. David flees to Zif, in Southern Hebron mountains.  Aside that the site is mentioned in Joshua 15:44, I Chr.  4:19, and Nehemiah 3:17-18. Eubsebsius mentions the site inhabited in the early 4th century, and bearing the tomb of prophet Habakuk.

properties.name: Ein Hakoreh?
properties.description: A water pool used for cattle. Excavations at this site in 1994 yielded evidence of  a large water reservoir from the Roman-Byzantine period, which was the source of the aqueduct to Eleuthropolis (Beit-Guvrin). This is apprerently ths site identified by some Byzantine era pilgrims (i.e. Paula and Thedosius) with "Ein Hakoreh"' or "Samson's Spring", where Samson hit a 1000 Philistines with a donkey's jawbone (Judges 15:14-19).

properties.name: Tel-Goded - Moresheth Gat?
properties.description: Biblical site said to be the hometown of prophet Micha (Alternative offer at Horvat Batzal). Saint Jerome says the site bears the tomb of Micha and a church..

properties.name: Horvat Batsal / Moresheth Gat?
properties.description: A site suggested to be identified with Moreshet Gath, hometown of prophet Micha. According to Saint Jerome the site bears the burial of Micha, and a church..

properties.name: Callirohi
properties.description: Thermal baths where Herod went for treatment (Wars 1 657(). Described also by Pliny the elder and mentioned in the Madaba Map. Identified by Zeetsen in 1806 here, at Alzhara springs. Excavated in 1985-1989 by strubel and proved to be used in the 1 century and again in the Byzantine period. It also had a port and a road to Machaerus.
